title: Monthly Check-In Thread
content:
Hello everyone! Welcome to the r/Anxiety monthly check-in thread. We want this to serve as casual community chat for anyone who wants to get or stay involved without having to make a full post. Plus you can use this as an easy way to give us feedback on what you like and don't like about the subreddit.

Our mod team also maintains an official mental health Discord server for people who prefer realtime community, venting, peer support and off topic chat. We hope to see you there! Join link: [https://discord.com/invite/9sSCSe9](https://discord.com/invite/9sSCSe9)

# Checking In

Let us know what's on your mind! This includes (but is not limited to) any significant life changes/events that have happened recently; an improvement or decrease in your mental health; any upcoming plans that you're looking forward to (or dreading); issues you're dealing with in your own local or extended community; general sources of stress or frustration in your daily life; words of advice or comfort you want to share with everyone; questions/comments/concerns you want to share with the moderators and community regarding the subreddit.

Thanks and stay safe,

The r/Anxiety Mod Team

title: What Are Some "Comfy" Movies/Shows/Documentaries That Help You Manage Your Symptoms?
content: By "comfy" I generally mean something wholesome, positive, and low-stakes that can help me take my mind off of the negative thoughts. I've been having a stressful January and could use some distractions. Feel free to recommend any relevant genre, fiction or not. Thanks in advance ♥

title: I may have to detransition and it's surprisingly crushing.
content: Those in the US who are up-to-date with politics probably know how much things are changing for trans people. The first domino of reverting the past decade of progress for LGBTQ+ rights has been pushed and it really looks like, both because I have to or for my safety, that I'm going to have to detransition. I thought that I had a pretty healthy relationship with my gender as in I don't hate my masculinity, however the thought of detransitioning is eating away at me. I don't mean to scare anyone, but I am struggling to handle the idea of living without transitioning. I am currently already suffering from anxiety due to moving into adulthood and this has made it so that I've spent every night hyperventilating for hours until I knock myself out. I don't know what to do or what to think and this anxiety has kept me from even doing the things I like. I want to crawl in a hole and just stop existing because I hate the idea of living in a country that hates me. I'm scared. I'm tired. And I'm just so sad. Im sorry.

title: I’m so confident when I’m drunk, why can’t I be when I’m sober?
content: It sucks, I have zero anxiety when I’m drinking and can actually hold a good conversation with people, but when I’m sober I start shaking and can’t complete a sentence without stuttering. It: terrible

title: Drank two litres of coffee and now can't sit or stand still.
content:
I filled up my litre coffee maker twice (4 x 500ml cups) when I ran out of pot I filled my pot. 

I 29/m have a hard time regulating anything, whenever I don't have weed I just swap substances and have way too much caffeine. 

If I don't stop soon I could eventually have a heart attack drinking that much and if it was beer I'd be still pretty buzzed. 

I should invest in decaf coffee incase I ever over indulge.

title: Found something to help those of us who get anxious when alone
content: So in the few months that I've been suffering noticeable GAD along with other forms of anxiety I've found I'm at my worst when I'm alone or feel alone. Recently I've discovered watching a game Playthrough or reaction video of someone using a face cam who's personality you vibe with really helps. It might sound silly but if you struggle with similar issues give it a try.

title: Does dissolving Clonazepam under your tongue make it kick in faster?
content:
As the title says, Im wondering if a normal 0.5mg Paxam tablet can be dissolved under your tongue to make it work faster while having a panic attack?

  
Ive tried it a couple of times and have had varying success so I don't know if it's all in my head. I know you can get specific type of tablets that dissolve, but these are just regular pills. Am I just wasting them?

title: How do I deal with anxiety about my boyfriend?
content: I apologize in advance, English is not my first language. So, I'm 21(f), and have been in a relationship for several months now. This is my first serious relationship, and I have never experienced such feelings before. I'll explain. I'm used to keeping track of the other person's mood, and when a bf responds in a way I'm not used to, I start to worry. Or when he doesn't answer me for a long time, my anxiety begins to fill my head with thoughts in the style of "something happened to him." It doesn't last long, but it is strong feeling, and it annoys and worries me terribly.  He says I can always turn to him for support if I have another anxiety attack, but I don't want to worry him. Do you have any tips on how to deal with this? Any advice would be very helpful.

title: Bit of hope for whoever needs it
content:
Hi!! I have been really active in this group in the past 4 months as I had a horrible 4 months of constant anxiety and intrusive thoughts about something happening to my loved ones. I put in the hard work, its not easy but I started going on long walks, fresh air whenever I could, magnesium supplements, anything that would help me sleep better, weekly therapy and mostly I’ve learnt to not be scared of my thoughts and let them be. After a horrible 4 months I’ve had a good week! Its not fully gone but it used to be 99% of my day worrying now its only a 5% of everyday and I’m sure that will go soon. 
IT GETS BETTER, keep working towards it. Wishing you all the best

title: I haven’t been anxious for a few weeks
content: I never thought I’d experience anxiety like this. I’ve had panic attacks, anxiety attacks, and severe anxiety the day after drinking, but never constant “normal” anxiety. I had it like that for 4 months, but now I’m laying in bed realising that I haven’t felt too bad for 2-3 weeks. I took my first shower alone today. I’ve had to bring my cats in with me up until today when I just randomly decided to do it alone and there was no problem. I do get anxious thoughts, but instead of making be anxious, I get depressed, with also some suicidal thoughts. In my experience, I’ll take suicidal thoughts and depression any day, over the anxiety. I am finally feeling calm. And I feel safe enough to actually let myself be calm, instead of checking for anxiety and thinking that it’s no use relaxing cause the anxiety will be back any second. I’ve been struggling with going to concerts because I’m scared I’ll get anxiety before it starts and I’ll have to leave. Tomorrow I’m going to a concert and I have absolutely no fear of it happening. The anxiety will probably return at some point, but at least now I can think back to this and remind myself that no matter how long of an episode I have, it will pass.

title: Avoiding the Dentist for 2 years
content:
Hi, I have a lot of anxiety around this issue and would like some advice. For context, I struggle with depression and anxiety, often leading to neglecting my health and wellness. 

Basically, I've completely ghosted my dentist. I feel awful and carry a lot of guilt over it. Plus, I am constantly worrying about my oral health now but am avoiding making an appointment because I feel like they will be angry with me/have probably dropped me as a patient by now. 

My question is: if I went to a new dental practice to start over with a different dentist, would that be ok? I have this fear that I'm registered as like an unreliable patient or something. That's not a thing, right?

title: Does anyone else's anxiety symptoms disappear when they have a cold or flu?
content: I'm just getting over a cold, and, for the duration of it, all my anxiety symptoms disappeared completely. I've noticed this in the past too. Has anyone else experienced this, and is there a particular reason why, I wonder?

title: Do anxiety meds truly help?
content:
So I’ve been dealing with Generalized Anxiety Disorder for abkut 2 and a half years now and lately it’s been ruining my quality of life and making me agoraphobic even, doing simple tasks like going to the grocery store and even in public is a challenge becauss I am always on high alert.

I’ve wanted to get over my anxiety naturally but everyday I am feeling anxious and I am always over thinking and my health anxiety is beyond bad.

What I am trying to ask is, are starting anxiety meds worth it? People who have been on them or tried them, what things did you notice that started to get better or worse??

title: Anxiety is going to ruin my relationship
content:
My partner is so, so patient with me, but I know eventually it's going to be too much. 

I'm terrified of losing him, but it means I keep asking him for reassurance that he still loves me and I'm not being too annoying and he doesn't want to break up with me.

I *know* asking wouldn't change anything if he was going to break up with me, and just might push him away, but I keep asking. 

He's so so so patient and reassures me he'd rather I ask him than worry, but I'd be annoyed with me so I'm worried he'll get tired of me to the point I can't fix things. 

What do I do? How do I manage this? It's like I've let my guard down and now I can't stop it.

title: A little positivity story
content:
Hi, I have GAD which made me feel like I was in a panic attack all day. Right now at 6:22, my nerves are calmed down a bit. 

I hope the same for your near future. I love you and it’s so hard but keep doing it.

title: I can’t enjoy the moment without going “what if”
content: I awoke to my mum hugging me and stroking my head, and she apologised for accidentally tugging my hair the other day. I was trying to enjoy it, I barely ever hug her. so immediately my brain went to what if. “Why is this happening?“ “what if this is a sign”??? I can’t enjoy normal human things without thinking something bad will happen. I can’t go into the city wirh my friends to have fun without thinking “what if this happens?“ Or I can’t even enjoy a movie I like because I’ll go “what if this happens during it?”. It’s driving me insane. I feel like I don’t deserve happiness for this.

title: It happened again...
content:
I built up the courage, I tried hard to get into a new hobby, I joined a group of like minded people, and today was this first gathering I could attend. I showed up early and the lot was full so I grabbed a "spot" at the back of the lot and waited. While I was waiting I apparently was blocking the driveway and a guy started honking at me, so I lurched forward to give him room, but now I couldn't get out of my car. So I try and reposition my car to fit in the "spot" and I just couldn't do it and my anxiety peaked and I started shaking and I just had to abandon the whole thing and race home. Now I'm nervous to say anything in the group and I'm nervous to go to the local hang out spot.

I just can't do group things, I don't know why. People don't wanna meet one on one as friends, it's always a group. I struggle with a group. Why is it so damn hard to make friends at 33 years old???

title: I Finally Had a Good Day.
content:
Hi everyone,

This is my first post in this forum, and I'm glad to say that it's a positive one. I've dealt with mental health problems for most of my life at this point. For the most part its been high highs and very low lows, but nothing consistent. For the past month or so I've been in a low period. This time things felt different. I was feeling like my anxiety would never go away... Today I woke up feeling better than I have in a long time.

I guess what I'm really trying to say is that sometimes your mental health has no true pattern. I don't know why I woke up feeling the way that I did, but I'm happy. I hope that my good day will make its way to the other members of this community. Additionally, I'm hoping that this reminder will encourage someone who doesn't want to go another day to go that extra day.

title: Does anyone else get dental anxiety? I overcame mine today!
content:
I hate the dentist. With a passion. I’ve been shamed, had tools drop down my throat, had freezing not work, and have had to fork over thousands of dollars in one go. I was putting it off for years but I knew multiple cavities were forming, I was grinding my teeth to stubs, and my wisdom teeth were in so much pain. The buildup of issues put me over the edge and weirdly I had this hope I’d die before I had to deal with my mouth. I just recently got benefits and realized I couldn’t delay the inevitable…I had to just get myself to the dentist. 

I didn’t sleep last night, and I was a wreck all morning but somehow I got myself to the dentist for the first time in years. The hygienist and dentist were incredible. I instantly blurted out an apology for the state of my teeth and was met with so much empathy. Zero shame, they were gentle, and educational. Set up a restorative plan with a fitting for a night guard as well and discussed the possibilities for wisdom teeth removal. Because of the way they spoke with me I was put at ease and feel I can attend my next appointment with less fear. I will do my very best not to cancel as I’ve done in the past. This small life win has me beaming today :)

title: Death anxiety at 20
content: Recently I’ve been having some strong death anxiety as I realize I’m 1/4th through my life. Depending on how tech advances maybe 1/5th if we actually figure some stuff out. But it doesn’t make it better that I’m still freaking out over the fact that I’m anywhere between 25-20% of the way done already. Certainly doesn’t help that I’m agnostic and have no idea wtf comes after death

title: I feel like I’ll never find a medication that will work :(
content:
Buspar: didn’t work

Effexor: kind of worked but prolonged my QT interval so I had to stop taking it

Desvenlafaxine: didn’t work

Lexapro: maybe slightly helped, but made me suuuper sleepy 

Celexa: helped a little bit, but it destroyed my appetite and I lost a lot of weight on it 

Low dose Seroquel: didn’t help, increased my heart rate to 130 an hour ish after taking it

Prozac: didn’t work

Propranolol: didn’t work

Clonidine: didn’t work 

Duloxetine: didn’t work

Any recommendations?? I’m getting really hopeless and feel like I’ll never find a med that will help me :(

title: do you also have these anxiety symptoms? is this anxiety or something else entirely?
content:
SYMPTOMS:
- Not good butterflies feeling in solar plexus area of my stomach

- Adrenaline like surges (not exactly how adrenaline rushes usually would feel but similar to it)

- Always always always tired

- Depersonalization/derealization

- Questioning my vision, feeling like I can see what’s in front of me but not being able to really comprehend what I’m seeing. Basically overthinking to the point I think I can’t comprehend something anymore.

- Fear of losing my mind or going insane

- Feeling a lack of relief (for example, when you’re nauseous you throw up and you feel better. when you’re sad, you cry and you feel better. but with this anxiety, feels like I need to rip off my skin or have a panic attack but I don’t even get a panic attack I just suffer for the entire day)

- Feeling intense brain fog, unable to comprehend certain things without really thinking. Forgetting words or phrases. 

- Overthinking/thought loops

- Intense feelings of hopelessness and dread “Will I always be stuck this way? Will this be how I am forever? Will I never be normal or able to live my life again?”

- Feeling uncomfortable uneasy “feelings” over the randomest of things. Certain numbers, words, things don’t “feel right” and I don’t understand why.

title: My Experience Overcoming Disordered Anxiety
content:
I wrote a piece on how I recovered from anxiety disorders on Medium. But, I don't know if this subreddit allows links to go through so I'll just share the whole story here. I feel like that's the last step of my recovery: self expression and sharing with others. I know that reddit subthreads can be discouraging and people don't speak of recovery and being on the other side of it, cause they're too busy living their lives. I've been reflecting on my experience so far and felt inspired to share with community that may need a message like that. So I'm sharing it here, here is the story in full:

# My Experience Overcoming Disordered Anxiety

I know if I were you, I wouldn’t want a 10-page long ramble session about someone’s life story. I’m assuming you clicked on this because either you or someone you know is experiencing disordered anxiety. I only hope to provide some insight through sharing my experience and I will be linking the sources that quite literally changed my life down below. With that being said, I want to make this as impactful and direct as possible so that it will hopefully leave you with some insights of your own. Here it is.

# Briefly About Me

My experience with disordered anxiety was intense. I’ve struggled with anxiety since I was 9, but for the last 2 years, I couldn’t leave the house. I couldn’t get in a car, use public transportation, go to grocery stores, do anything really, you name it. It got to the point that I would have a panic attack walking 5 minutes up my neighbourhood and I would have to turn around. Now, that’s crazy, right? Not as crazy as actually thinking you were going crazy and feeling unreal, which is also a very common symptom of severely disordered anxiety. So, what were my labels: Agoraphobia, Panic Disorder, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Derealization and Depersonalization.

That was me at 22 years old. But, about a week ago, I celebrated my 24th birthday with people I love in crowded restaurants, movie theatres, and bars. I’ve been going on long drives, and planning trips. Weirdly enough, it *feels* like those last 2 years never happened. Though, I reflect on those years quite a lot to this day, which is what inspired me to write this.

# So, What Happened?

The experience of being homebound freaked me out so much that I looked into every method, tip, and solution under the sun. From CBT to CBD. From SE to IFS. From A to Z. I did them. Some of them did help to a certain extent, and they had the right idea because they attempted to steer me away from my thoughts and bring my attention to the sensations in the body, but it wasn’t enough. I would go right back to what I was doing: overthinking. I would spend hours in my bedroom feeling like I was close to a solution, without having made any progress in reality. The reality was, I was just in my room… thinking. I thought I was on the right track to finding an answer to conquer anxiety and finally leaving my house again. **Little did I know, that anxiety was not a problem to be solved, and not a problem at all.**

What do I mean by that? Now, before I go into what *was* effective for me, I want to set a bit of a realistic expectation. **Recovering from anxiety is not a one-size-fits-all situation.** Everyone is different, so take what you need and leave the rest. Medication was not part of my journey but it can be a wonderful tool for many. We can all reach the same destination by taking different paths. We are all unique and so our paths will be too, but recovery is possible for everyone. I am simply sharing my personal experience.

**I outline anxiety in a really simplistic manner and that is done intentionally.** Simplicity was key, in my experience because overcomplicating anxiety made me resist the discomfort and prolonged my suffering for years. As I was recovering, I had many moments of pain and discomfort, and it was a gradual process where I had to experience something several times until I believed everything I was taught. **We all want a quick solution but we usually learn through repetition, and experiencing the challenge firsthand.** You’ll face the same lessons repeatedly and that’s perfectly normal. That is the point! Every small step back towards your life, despite how it feels, is a step towards coming back to yourself. So, what does that look like?

# What I Learned

**Let me start this off by saying, our body is always working in our favour, even during a panic attack.** This sentiment alone sparked monumental shifts in my recovery. I hated panic attacks, they were the bane of my existence. My intense fear of panic is what kept me homebound. I even forced myself to face my fears and be willing to feel panic just so I would *not* feel panic — didn’t work, of course. Force doesn’t make sense here because that adds more pressure which disrupts our nervous system even more. I truly started making strides in recovery once I stopped fearing panic attacks. This is what I learned about them:

* **Panic attacks are adrenaline rushes.** Adrenaline pumps through our body to keep us ***alive,*** not to kill us. In times of danger, it is our superpower by numbing our pain and giving us super strength, and energy for the situation. When the adrenaline is needed and used, a panic attack wouldn’t occur. **Adrenaline has a function, it is working in our favour.**
* Leading to my next point, ***the only cause of a panic attack is a whole lot of overthinking.*** Think about it (no pun intended), if adrenaline is put to use in the right circumstances, there is no space to think, we just act. The blood rushes to the big muscle groups in the right circumstances, we don’t have to plan, we don’t fear the adrenaline itself. We don’t have a panic attack.
* So, this means, it isn’t the grocery store causing your panic attack, nor is it any external situation. It is always your thinking about the experience, or your *overthinking* about it.
* Our system is designed for the “now”, it is not sophisticated enough to realize the brain is imagining a scary scenario. Therefore, panic attacks can work as an alarm that we are unintentionally misusing our system and our imagination. It works as a wake-up call to come back to reality.
* Our bodies are constantly healing and regenerating. So, all we need to do is trust in our natural healing system to bring us back to balance, more on that later.
* Our brain is a pattern recognition machine that uses information from the past to predict the future. It’s simply doing its job. **It can’t comprehend what it hasn’t experienced yet.** It doesn’t even make sense a lot of the time, it is so impersonal and random. **There is nothing new to learn from a repetitive machine, we can take it less seriously.**
* When there is nothing to immediately act on, it can feel uncomfortable. The energy seeks release, but we often misinterpret it as dangerous, leading to a panic attack. Panic attacks are simply a fear of fear itself. **The discomfort is a good indicator that you are safe.**
* We can overthink and stress ourselves out about symptoms so much that we can dissociate, disconnect from our surroundings, and feel unreal. **This is also a signal that our brain is tired and in need of rest.**
* **My favourite point: an adrenaline rush has a shelf-life of 8 minutes, and a half-life of 4 minutes.**

# Here’s Why This Was Relevant for Me

***You think you want liberation from this anxious energy when the truth is, it wants liberation from you. This is why it keeps coming up; it wants to be free of you, just as much as you want to be free of it. — Paul David***

Here is the thing, if you went to the doctor’s office, and they told you they were going to inject you with adrenaline but it would leave the system completely within 8 minutes, and start to fade within the first 4 minutes, how different would your experience be? Chances are, you’d feel the symptoms of the adrenaline but with a sense of security, then it would pass in 8 minutes. Would that turn into a panic disorder? It wouldn’t. The energy wants to move through you, it wants to be liberated from you too.

This is the case for every anxiety symptom — **every painful symptom you currently have will gradually dissipate once you learn to trust that the body is always working in your favour, whether you realize it or not.** It may take some time, and there may be days that are more painful than others, but that is a natural part of the process, it is expected. We are built to tolerate discomfort, have you ever been sore from a workout, or broken a bone? How different was your experience when you didn’t have to worry about it?

Understanding all of this brought a sense of ease and confidence in my experience. Now, it wasn’t a battle against anxiety, why would it be? Panic attacks and all anxious symptoms became neutral and impersonal alarms that I interpreted as a sign of my overthinking. It wasn’t the car, the place, the person — I just had distorted thinking running through my head. I slowly started to believe that my symptoms weren’t against me and that made a world of a difference in tolerating the discomfort. I understood that being in real-time danger would leave no space to overthink, **because thinking does not keep me safe**. That was mind-blowing for an over-thinker like me.

# On a Deeper Note

I was taught how our bodies always return to balance, how it is *designed* to return to balance. When we break a bone, we don’t have to overthink it into healing, nor do we have to do that with the flu, or soreness from a workout. **We can tolerate those feelings and still be involved with our life and what matters to us.** They don’t become front-page news. We also don’t overthink to get our heart to beat, or grow babies. It happens on its own. There is less for us to do.

As I believed what I learned more, I started to be filled with wonder at how beautifully we are designed, in ways beyond our control. We are nature and nature is intelligent: forest fires work as beneficial component for a healthy ecosystem, planets can spin and orbit the sun, flowers know when to bloom and how to face the sun. T**here is no thinking involved**. This sparked more ease within me. I trusted my body so much more to do what it was already doing, that made all of the difference. So anxiety was never anything to solve, it became a helpful alarm that I was using my head too much. I slowly started seeing how much life I had missed out on because I was so involved with my thoughts, and that kept me stuck, to a very serious extent. **And** i**f you feel stuck you need to do something different in order to yield different results. We can’t achieve this through overthinking**. I do believe it is that simple.

These experiences are not personal to most people, but for some reason, people with disordered anxiety take anxiety very personally. None of us are doing this on purpose, it is a misunderstanding of the system. But, taking it personally is what kept me stuck. I took it so seriously, and I thought it was a real problem. I wouldn’t beat myself up for wanting rest and fluids if I had the flu, for example. Once my attitude around it changed, things started to change.

**I reflected on how, when my car is freezing cold and I turn the heat on, I don’t suffer in the cold because I know the car will warm up soon.** I like to think of panic attacks and recovering from disordered anxiety in the same light. Once our attitude towards it has a sense of ease and openness, the experience shifts. As I moved forward, each uncomfortable experience became an opportunity to see the truths I had learned play out in real-time.

# What Changed Afterwards?

This had already sparked me to stretch out my comfort zone in the smallest ways. This time it wasn’t through force but through curiosity and a true willingness to get back to my life. I started doing the things that were important to me again, which was going on a walk, for example. I would feel that adrenaline rush and I would see it as my superpower strength fired off in the wrong scenario. The experience was not *that* scary anymore. **So, I slowly abandoned myself to how I felt and went back to my life.** I treated lingering symptoms the same way I would treat sore muscles. There was a lot of repetition here, and I thought “Oh, maybe I can do this. Oh, and then this? And then maybe this!” but it happened through a *wanting* to do it vs. forcing myself to do it to overcome pain. It was in the spirit that I was doing it in.

I started with walks which turned to going to stores, then restaurants, and eventually taking shuttle buses which took me 9 hours away from home. **This sounds linear but I have to emphasize that it wasn’t.** Each step forward — however daunting — became a milestone in my journey. Even when it felt like I was going backwards, which *we never can by the way*. So, what might that look like for you? Remember, nothing is too small.

Worrying and overthinking became irrelevant after learning that. I do believe it is that simple. I’m still human and I worry from time to time, but my relationship with this entire experience is drastically different. More importantly, I don’t fear my experience and it doesn’t dictate what I do. I like to see moments of worry and discomfort as opportunities to see my imagination at play and come back to reality. Looking back, from a calm and clear mind, I can really see the gift in it and my intention was to highlight that (even just a little bit) here. I hope this helped, friends!

# Resources

To end it off, here are three resources that were the most impactful throughout my journey:

Lily Sais (@peacefromwithin) — alongside her free content — I highly recommend joining her community as well. It is affordable, you can speak with her directly, and be part of a supportive community.

Sarie Taylor (@sarietaylorcoaching)

Paul David (“At Last a Life” Book)

Let me know if you're curious to see the Medium article itself! :) I don't know if I'm allowed to link it.

title: Why am i feeling like this?
content: I have always been a bit shy to situations in public but after working a job for a year in a restaurant i’ve become a lot more sociable. But for some reason for the first time ever i feel physically sick, nauseous and lightheaded at the thought of going to class, i’ve never felt like this and ive been through high school, ive already had half a year of uni and i never felt like this before. I just want to be able to feel fine with going to class, why do i feel so sick?

title: My girlfriend has anxiety and it effects our relationship
content: I been dating this girl for a while now and she has anxiety. I know nothing about anxiety and it hasn’t really been much of an issue until recently. Shes been telling me she’s fine she’s obviously not and stuff like that and recently the smallest things have been ruining her whole day. Like she’ll get scared something bad is happening to her and say that she’s dying and stuff like that if something on her body hurts. Or like something minor like spilling water on herself will happen and it will ruin her whole day. Every time I try and help she’s just been saying I that I don’t understand anxiety which is true I don’t know anything abt it. So i’m just asking for help because I really wanna make her feel comfortable or just like help her out. What can I do to help.

title: Old hobbies give me a headache
content:
I love playing video games and watching dragon ball, but now everytime I play or watch it, I get a headache. 

I know it doesn’t sound that bad, but when your biggest fear is a stroke then you can’t not think about it. 

I am 17 with a great blood test and great ECG results, also got anxiety. 

I’ve also been getting a cold wet patch feeling in my left arm in the same spot all the time and it’s really bothering me now

title: Eating and anxiety
content: Lately when I eat especially at night I’m chewing more and more and thinking every bite through I don’t know what to do to get my mind off it and what to use to distract me. I’ve tried tv, videos it doesn’t work. Anyone deal with this and what do u do to help?

title: Do you guys also struggle to enjoy or focus on pretty much anything? I have a lot of books and shows and stuff I wanna read or watch, but I feel afraid to start anything because it feels like something bad is gonna happen to me at any moment, and it's pointless to do anything :(
content: I miss being able to just focus on things. Some things do help and distract me enough, kind of. It's still always in the back of my head though. It's gotten so bad.

title: Feeling of impending doom but have no guts to do anything about it.
content:
My depression, anxiety and ocd has spiraled out of control and made my job performance at work horrible. And I've cut contacts with many coworkers except ones I have projects to work with them. Skipped all social events due to nearly breaking down at one in the spring. Manager tells me I had no motivation to do original work despite knowing well I am having bad mental health (he saw me taking antidepressant after panicking).

Really felt angry at everything, but I now feel like I've ruined my life choices by doing this. I never felt focused during work after years of burning out at highschool, college and master's. I started to being bad at forming even simple phrases and remembering things.

Now, I am worried I might get kicked out after a year of this. Manager and skip aren't responding to me after performance review. I've tried to resume working as much as possible but they never gave me new stuff to work on. I can feel something bad is coming for my career trajectory.

I don't want to even want to work any more, future just makes me anxious. I don't want to think I have to plan out more than a year from now. I have no friends to contact right now and my family's getting tired of my mental crisis. I used to love cycling, but my contamination OCD is actively ruining it, along with angry drivers on road trying to run me over and shorten daytime. I stopped getting excited for video games. Only thing I do is bingewatch netflix shows at this point and trying to forget my reality. I think temperature dropping is also having an effect in making me anxious, but I can't be so sure.

title: Feeling weird by NOT having anxiety?
content:
Hey everyone, first time posting here. I’ve suffered from severe anxiety (general, social, and agoraphobia) for 16 years. My anxiety goes through its phases: sometimes it’s manageable (but still there) other times it’s debilitating where I can’t even leave the house.

Recently had some severe, different anxiety that was brought on by talks/thoughts of marriage and having kids with my girlfriend of 3 years. It’s like my every day anxiety brought on by doing regular tasks has disappeared because my mind is preoccupied by another HUGE life milestone. 

Now that I’ve calmed down a bit from the prospect of those thoughts, I don’t really have any anxiety (for now) for the past few days, other than the occasional racing thought. While it’s a huge welcome and blessing, considering I was so held down by anxiety for so long and was in a dark place not that long ago, it feels…odd.

I don’t know how to explain it but it’s almost like my mind is craving those anxious thoughts to feel “normal” again. I should be ecstatic to not be feeling anxious but I just feel weird and not normal without that anxiety.

Can anyone else relate to this and provide tips on moving forward?

Thank you!

title: Recovering From Panic Attacks?
content:
I've had a very weird time lately with my anxiety. Last week, I had 2 panic attacks out of nowhere. I've never had any before. The first one was in my car and I recovered quickly and felt better the rest of the day. The second one I felt exhausted from, so I just went to bed. I proceeded to have the worst disrupted sleep ever including a nightmare.

The next day, I felt dizzy, lightheaded, and fatigued all day. I assumed I would just be fine in the next day but that was 5 days ago. 

I did recover from the fatigue and dizziness, but ever since then, I've still had this general feeling of unease and discomfort that won't leave even when distracting myself. It's not my typical anxiety, where I would worry about something specific like school, but still be fine and able to relax with a movie or special interest. I am just constantly uneased and feeling a bit apathetic. I can't relax or feel excitement. I've even lost my appetite and sex drive which is really concerning me. I'll have mood swings, where one second I think I'm feeling fine but then the next second the feeling is back. I think it's generally being triggered by thinking about the anxiety. Thinking about the anxiety that I had just makes me more anxious.

I have a doctor's appointment in a couple days to discuss this. I feel like I should also get some blood work and a long-awaited referral to a therapist. In the meantime, I was wondering if anyone has ever experienced something like this and recovered? It's such a hard feeling to explain that I feel bad for rambling on about. I just hope I will be feeling better in a week.

title: How is your health anxiety affecting your life?
content:
Things I deal with:

1. I developed agoraphobia because I am convinced something bad will happen to my life when I am somewhere far from home, like going at the beach, being too long outside, shopping alone in big supermarkets, eating in a canteen alongside strangers etc

2. I literally limit myself when it comes to daily, normal activities because my health anxiety has convinced me that I need to rest and not overwork so as soon as my heart rate elevates, I stop doing whatever I was doing or make several breaks

3. I avoid getting excited because I feel so tense and more bad than good when I get excited, therefore watching something fun, playing video games, enjoying things in general is literally impossible to me at this point because my heart rate skyrockets, which is normal function of heart  under some circumstances but I experience it in negative way

title: Anything you do to help stay present
content: Something simple and I can do in bed I’m panicking about the future again

title: Sertraline Replacements?
content:
I have been on Sertraline 100 MG for the Lord knows how long (+5 years). However, I no longer have health insurance and am out of my refills. I take them once daily, but lately I’ve been trying to go every other day to make them last as long as I can.

My worry of going cold turkey is the brain/body zaps- they are unbearable for me and cause such bad headaches; so I’m trying to ween off by doing every other day.

Is it possible to get a Sertraline script without having to see my PCP?
If not, has anyone used any other vitamins/herbs to replace the antidepressant? Or to help the zaps?
Does anyone have tips on how to handle this situation? Sorry, I’ve never not had health insurance so this is my first time navigating this…

title: Waking up anxious on the days I go to work even though I like my job
content:
I guess this is sort of a rant but I’m also curious if anyone has had or is having an experience similar to me because it just feels so weird.

I (24F) have been dealing with anxiety (GAD) since middle school. My anxiety always has been triggered by big changes, so transitioning from middle to high school was a huge challenge and then high school to college was also rough, but I made it through. Each time, I just needed some time to get used to the new situation and eventually I was fine. After the initial transition period, I could go months or even years without feeling a single ounce of anxiety. I’ve grown a lot and learned a lot about my anxiety since I was younger, some things have changed, but that was something that always stayed constant: after the transition period, after I got comfortable where I was, whether at a new school or new job, the anxiety eventually subsided. 

Not this time. This time it’s weird (compared to what I’ve experienced in the past with my anxiety) and I’m so frustrated and confused. Basically, I started a new job at the end of August last year. I had a little bit of anxiety during the transition (to be expected). But it was actually a lot better than it had been in the past. September comes and goes and I’m doing pretty well, getting used to the new job. Then October hits and things change. I’m not sure if it was my medication or what (I was seeing a psychiatrist that was not great who I have since stopped seeing, I think maybe she changed something but I honestly don’t even remember). During transition periods/periods of high anxiety, my anxiety is often worse in the mornings. This isn’t new. What was new that mainly started in October was that I started throwing up in the mornings (never happened before) and waking up shaking with my heart racing. The shaking and heard racing would happen during periods of high anxiety in the past, but never did I just wake up like that. What is so weird to me is it’s not like I woke up and started overthinking and getting in my head and THEN got anxious. I literally wake up anxious. It’s like I wake up and my body is in fight or flight mode. Shaking, heart racing, throwing up. FOR NO REASON!!! That’s the thing! I literally love my new job, I finally feel like I’m in a great place, I’m getting married this year, we’re moving in together soon…and yes I know what you’re thinking, that’s a lot of big life changes, that could be causing some of the anxiety. And yes, maybe a little bit. But that’s normal big life changes anxiety. Not waking up in the morning throwing up anxiety. Is it? Either way, here’s where it gets weirder…this only happens on days that I go to work. Weekends I’m completely fine. Sometimes Sunday nights I get a little uneasy because I anticipate that morning anxiety, but like Monday we had off and I was totally fine. Reminder: I really like my job!!! Plus, the majority of the day I’m fine! It’s literally only from the moment I wake up to when I walk in the building at work. Then it goes away and I enjoy my day. WTF???

God I’m SO frustrated. Throughout all of this and throughout my life, I have seen many therapists, psychiatrists, psychologists, etc. I am seeing a therapist now who I’ve been with for a while, she’s amazing and she has been giving me a lot of good strategies to help me get through the mornings. I am also seeing a new psychiatrist and am currently working on a list of all of the medications I’ve taken in the past and trying to remember what helped and what didn’t to help give her some more information. Some of the meds I’ve tried in the past are bupropion (wellbutrin), gabapentin (neurontin), aripiprazole (abilify), lamotrigine (lamictal), desvenlafaxine (pristiq), clonazepam (klonipin), sertraline (zoloft), propranolol (inderal), busprione (burpar)…to name a few lol (that’s literally all of them). I’m currently on duloxetine (cymbalta) and have been on it for years, but the new doc suggested I try to come off of it and try escitalopram (lexapro) instead. I think I was on lexapro many many years ago but I honestly don’t remember so we’re going to give it a shot. Most recently, I also tried prazosin (minipress) but it had no effect. 

Thank you if you read all this. Again, I’m mainly ranting bc I’m so frustrated and I feel like my brain/body is making miserable for no reason, but I am curious if anyone has experienced anything like this before, if you got past it and how.

content: Earlier today I suddenly got this feeling that something bad was going to happen. It just crept up on me and it feels like a tingling in my back and shoulders and I can’t shake it. I have good intuition and so I’m worried that this is my intuition telling me something bad is gonna happen. Anyone else ever feel like this? Idek what would happen but I’m just worried.

title: Lost everything losing hope
content: I'll start from the beginning, when I was 9 I got sexually abused my by cousin (f16) and got addicted to porn, from 9 to 14 I had a semi normal life, my parents were abusive emotionally but at least i had alot of good friends but when i turned 14 i started to get social anxiety, I'd never had it before but all the sudden I was uncomfortable around friends, family, any social situations, then I lost my grandpa, my parents were always abusive emotionally but my grandpa was like the supportive dad I never had, when he died I was going into high school, I went to a different school then all of my other friends so I was alone as a freshmen in high-school with bad anxiety and I just lost my grandpa, then everything started getting worse, I got really depressed and then started getting bullied, I was never the "weird kid", I was always just a normal kid and all the sudden now I wasn't, i didn't know why but I was so anxious all the time, 6 months into freshmen year i faked having a health condition so I didn't have to go to school anymore, it only got worse though, my parents tried forcing me to go back to school but I didn't want to so we fought really bad and eventually they believed me about the health condition, for a while I was better not having to go to school but then I just got really depressed and started having suicidal thoughs alot, I wasn't leaving the house at go see a doctor, I don't know if I'll ever be able to live a normal life like this😭😭 honestly I'm just so tired of living like this and I needed to vent on here, I'm 16 now and I have no friends, no future, i faked a medical condition and now I'm lying to my parents, I don't know what to do anymore and I'm tired😭😓

title: too anxious for therapy
content:
hey everyone, i was recently diagnosed with GAD and social anxiety, along with emetophobia (fear of vomit). i’ve been seeing my therapist for a little over a year now, but we started doing online sessions because i would get so anxious coming in. we decided to go back to in person sessions recently, and ive been a mess. i’m terrified of throwing up there, or potentially catching something that could make me sick. and im in my head the entire time about myself and being self conscious and it’s hard to focus on the session or not let my anxiety do the talking. and im not sure why it’s been getting worse but now it gets to the point that every morning before therapy i get so worked up and anxious that i end up making myself sick and throwing up. i was recently also prescribed lexapro, which i’ve only been taking for 1.5 weeks so i haven’t noticed any effects yet, me and my therapist were hoping it’ll start to improve when the meds start to work, if they do. this is my first time trying meds too and im terrified. 
sorry im rambling now, i have therapy tomorrow and i can’t sleep thinking about it so im posting this. does anyone have any advice like how to handle the situation? usually once im actually in the appointment its okay but the anxiety is so intense most of the time i just end up cancelling. how do you guys deal with situational anxiety like that? and has anyone been on lexapro for anxiety?

title: Random impending doom/adrenaline rushes?
content: Does anyone else have moments where you will just be relaxing, then all of the sudden your chest feels like it drops/sinks in and you get a HORRIBLE impending doom/adrenaline rush. Just feels like something is horribly wrong? My cardiologist doesn’t think I have any cardiac related issues but the occasional palpitations, weird chest sensations, make me believe other wise. When the adrenaline rush happens for me, I don’t have palpitations, chest just sinks and I instantly feel something is wrong.

title: Anyone on anything that doesn’t make them feel like a zombie? I also have seizures
content:
I feel like I’ve tried everything under the sun, and they either make me numb and lifeless or they give me seizures. Enter in “anti-seizure” medications that also work as mood stabilizers, those give me absence seizures too. I went off Wellbutrin (it was working great) because it was increasing the amount of seizures I get. I didn’t have any until I started Lamotrigine yesterday, and have had three since. 

I’m getting really frustrated and just want something to work. I have really bad anger bursts that I think is linked to anxiety, and I just want to calm down. It feels like I’m always at a simmer just waiting to boil over.

title: Pretty sure I bombed a test due to a panic attack
content:
First time posting here but I need to talk about this

I’m taking APUSH and am one of four students who were allowed to take it two years early. Previously I have had no experience with test anxiety, I could go in and get an A every time in every class. It has been my goal to be Valedictorian, something that I’m pretty sure is a goal I share with like two other people which was my main motivation in taking the class early to pace myself on getting all my AP’s done. First term of APUSH I did great and got an A+, 100% on the dbq final. However, I noticed myself having a lot more anxiety before, during, and after tests. This term is a whole other story as some of the people in my class are like on another level of gifted. I’ve always been smart but had to work at it more than a lot of my peers in advanced classes. Every discussion I’ve been filled with anxiety and beat myself up over answering questions. I don’t get along with my teacher great who seems completely puzzled by the amount of questions I ask and when I ask for help. Now today came for my first unit test, a combination of periods 4 and 5. I studied hours, did practice mcq’s and saq’s, did great on the progress checks in AP classroom. I walk into class feeling like I could pass out but sit down and start the test. I get through the mcq part easily and start to type my saq, it was so frickin easy too but I started to hear everyone type and could imagine them going from question to question with no problem and I genuinely had to focus on not vomiting on the table and debating if I needed to literally run to the bathroom and throw up. I have no idea what came over me but I was holding back tears and all of a sudden I couldn’t spell or write sentences. Before I knew it I got parts A and B of 1/2 saq’s done and class was almost over. Holy crap I left a whole saq blank. I asked my teacher if I could come in and finish it up and I was sure he’d say yes as he has ALWAYS let people do that and he said no. I just started silently sobbing. I tried to get something on the page but I was shaking so hard and I couldn’t stop thinking about how I looked so dumb. This was supposed to be my best performance on a test, I always do so good on the writing portions and I just bombed it. 

I feel like my life is kind of over. I prepared myself more than ever before and did so much practice over the weekend and the morning of watched the heimler history videos. I’m sorry if this comes off as ramble-y or if I just sound like I’m whining but this is the first time I’ve really messed up THIS bad.

title: DARE Technique opinions?
content:
I started struggling again with severe anxiety about two years ago after my SSRI just stopped working for me, and i have been practicing DARE ever since. I feared that i would have another medication stop working again , so i started really going the natural route and practicing DARE.

Anyone else feel like no matter how long and committed they are to practice accepting the anxiety and letting it be, the symptoms are still very much present and uncomfortable? 

I was hoping that this method would really help my anxiety, and yes ive become more tolerant of it and able to function with it. Regardless, I still always feel like shit and with high levels of anxiety after strictly practicing acceptance and exposures for two years. 

anyone else feel the same? i think its time to give up and try some new meds. ive tried it all, but nothing provides relief like paxil (ssri) did for a couple of years and im tired of never feeling comfortable in my body.

title: I don't want to let everyone down
content: So in about 4 months time im going to have to take my entrance exams. Im not aware of how the school system is in other counties tho. I have been feeling extreme anxiety due to pressure from my parents, relationships (both romantic and none) constantly falling apart. And well, disappointing myself with the amount of time I study. I have set everyone's expectations so high but I feel as if im ruining myself. I feel as if im going to let everyone down, disappoint them myself included. I just want to be seen as smart or someone to well, have as their role model. But i just end up being the smart kid who will probably fail because he doesn't study enough. My friendships are also starting to slightly fade away. My friends got a lot of studying to do and I get it. I don't want to pressure them. But I have been feeling lonely and I just want someone to be by my side through this tough time. I have also been going through a lot due to my romantic relationships. Such as breakups, pressure in general again, and overall anxiety. I also recently lost my grandfather and despite not being that close to him it hurt, it hurt because he was the first person I ever lost and it just had to happen in this hellhole of a year. I just feel as if my body and mind is crumbling apart and i cant take anymore anxiety but it just keeps on coming. This whole post is just a whole lot of messy writing and most of it might not even make sense but I just had to. I had to share it somewhere because I cant keep it by myself anymore..

title: I don’t want to drink water
content:
TLDR: I’m worried about drinking a gallon of water a day and slowly poisoning myself. 

I grew up drinking from a full reverse osmosis filter and quality drinking water and I have been very particular because I am a water enjoyer. I recently moved and don’t want to have to buy huge gallons of water when I aim for a gallon a day that’s $3 a day x 365. 

But, I also can’t install a big water system. I’m worried about microplastics and chemicals / impurities in the tap water (which other people drink the chlorine just freaks me out) but I don’t want to get a Brita filter and it strip out minerals and potentially add unhealthy things as well..

What should I do? I drank some tap water which is safe I just really don’t like it. 

Edit: I am calling “tap water” water that comes from the fridge which is apparently filtered but still tastes very off and chlorinated.

title: Anxiety is effecting my work & I fear I might get fired
content:
I had anxiety since forever but in past few years, it got worse and lost a lot because of it. I have no friends I have  a voice in my head that never shuts up. I'm so tired mentally & physically. I am working as admin assistant. 

I've working at my new job for more than 2 months. I am the most useless person there ( just like I am in every aspect of my life). I don't fit in. Everybody hates me there. I live alone outside my work I've no one to talk to. 

So far, my interactions with everyone has been awkward and forced. Sometimes I am not able to reply back sometimes because of how overstimulated I got. I was fired from my first job in less than a month because of my anxiety. I fear this would happen to me again. They haven't assigned much work. I've to request them for more tasks. They have a unique administrative setting compared to other places  I worked.

If I got fired, I'm completely done with my life. This fear is taking over my life. I am scared to go to work. I am having panic attacks everyday because of my work. I have no one to hangout with that can distract me. It's horrible.

title: Scared About High Calcium Lvl On My Labs!
content:
A couple months ago, my doctor ordered a full lab test on me since I was complaining about insomnia and fatigue. The day I went to get my labs done, I barely slept for almost 4 days, was dehydrated and extremely stressed out. I was dissociating like crazy that day. A couple weeks later I got my labs back, and pretty much everything was fine except my calcium, being at 10.6 which is supposed to be 10.3 or lower!

I went to the doctor for a prescription refill on December 5th, and he went over my lab results. Everything was good but he requested me to do another test for specifically calcium. I'm really freaking out right now! I'm afraid it might be cancer even though I'm feeling A LOT better these days. I no longer have insomnia, my sleep has been restored and my fatigue has mostly gotten better. I'm just worried that I'm slowly dying of cancer! I'm also scared to go and get that calcium test. I hate health related shit SO MUCH!

I have MASSIVE health anxiety... Anyone else been in a similar spot?

title: What anxiety symptoms did Sertraline relieve for you?
content: So I was diagnosed with GAD and panic disorder a couple of months ago. The panic attacks have settled down THANK GOD, but I can still feel a lot of annoying symptoms of the anxiety (tight chest, left side of body in pain, occasional headache, insomnia, tension in shoulders and jaw, developed some cardiophoba and agoraphobia in the process, and ofcourse the feeling of always being on edge). I’ve been avoiding taking medication for it but I think I’m starting to open up to it officially. I was prescribed Sertraline but it’s just sitting there for weeks now. So I wanted to know (and I know everyone reacts to medication differently so I’m looking for people who benefited from Sertraline)…what symptoms did Sertraline/Zoloft relieve for you? Did you feel a noticeable difference and for how long? Thanks!

title: Feeling Stuck, Overwhelmed, and Regretful About My Current Job
content:
I don’t even know where to start, but I just need to get this off my chest. I’m currently working in childcare, and honestly, I regret taking this job. I thought it would at least be a little fun, or maybe even fulfilling, but it’s turned out to be the exact opposite.

The environment I’m in is anything but professional. My coworkers and management are, for lack of a better term, lazy and unmotivated. There’s so much toxicity here, and it feels like people are just out for themselves. If there’s ever a problem or disagreement, no one tries to sit down and discuss it like adults. Instead, they snap at you like they’re in some sort of gang.

This is such a stark contrast to the professional settings I’ve worked in before, where issues came up (because they always do) but were addressed calmly and constructively. Here, it’s like everyone’s walking on eggshells, and the second something doesn’t go someone’s way, it’s chaos.

On top of all that, I’m a foreigner working in a new country, and honestly, everything feels overwhelming. It’s already hard enough trying to adapt to a new culture and work environment, but being stuck in this toxic job just makes it so much worse. I feel completely out of place.

What makes it even harder is that I’m scared to open up to my husband and his family about how I’m feeling. This is my first job in this country, and they’re all so career-oriented and successful. I feel like they’ll judge me if I tell them how much I’m struggling. I don’t want to come off as a crybaby or as someone who can’t handle things. But the truth is, I feel like I’m barely holding it together. I’ve been trying so hard to keep my head above water, but it’s exhausting. I’ve been applying to other jobs for months now, but so far, nothing has come through. I feel completely stuck, and it’s taking a toll on me in ways I didn’t expect.

On top of everything, I’ve already been diagnosed with depression, and this job is only making things worse. I’m not just mentally drained—I’m physically exhausted as well. It feels like this job is sucking the life out of me, and I don’t know how much longer I can keep this up. Iguess I’m just here to vent and maybe find some solidarity. Have any of you been in a similar situation? How did you get through it? I don’t want to give up entirely, but I’m starting to feel like that might be my only option.

Any advice or encouragement would mean the world to me right now.

title: I am amazed at what I achieved and never realized w
content:
I'm amazed at how I managed to get good grades in my student days even with my social anxiety.
I also manage to go out and eat alone in a restaurant. Even working in a small shop as a seller and cashier.
Now thinking about working with people and having more responsibilities, I feel that it triggers my CPTSD and my social anxiety.
What I realized, and it coincides with what the psychologist tells me, is that one or two breaks help during a work day.

title: Panic attack over someone overhearing me at work
content:
I was talking to a coworker I'm very close with, and talking about some issues I'm having with another colleague. It's been very stressful, with the colleague trying to get me in trouble with our boss.

I was telling my coworker was was going on, and then saw one of our other colleagues standing outside my door like she was listening. This colleague is friends with the aforementioned other colleague. I am losing my mind that she will find out I was talking about her. I wasn't "talking shit" or anything, just explaining what happened and that I am upset. Obviously it was not all positive, but it was definitely not unkind.

title: Generalized Anxiety About Getting Into Violent Situations
content:
I think a lot about, and imagine scenarios where I go out, and get into an accident in my car(got into 2 recent accidents that weren't my fault). I imagine myself going to do general things like grocery store, and being challenged by a stranger, ending in me beating them. I feel anxious that my neighbor will do something that will cause me to argue with them, and eventually fight them. 

I am constantly imagining scenarios where I am put in situations that force me to fight, or use more aggravated ways of violence. I am extremely fearful of the consequences of my actions, but I know if put in such tight situations, my instinct and impulse will not be to walk away, but to escalate. And that scares me. 

I am an ex felon, who did their time 6 years ago. I am still on probation for that, and I'm constantly scared that my freedom will be taken away by something outside of my control. 

The truth is, I don't go out unless it's absolutely necessary. Groceries, reporting to probation, and occasionally going out after being begged enough by my girlfriend. 

I do my groceries at the earliest hour they open, wash my clothes at a 24hr laundry and go past midnight. I'm not working right now, but I will have to find work soon. I lived in a place where I owned the property but not the land, I and the rest of the people there were evicted and I'll be forced to find a job soon. My current rent is only paid till April. I dread the thought of being stuck in traffic, dealing with shitty people, it takes a lot of restraint to not want to hurt them. I feel that I'm surrounded by morons who like to test people's patience and I'm afraid of being incarcerated over someone I just couldn't walk away from. But I also don't want to live in constant restraint. 

I have a strong desire to leave the city and retire off into a home with land and no neighbors around me, but I'm stuck where I am because of probation and I also need the money for that. I'd like to either find employment as a starting line cook, to eventually move up as I have a passion for cooking and I want a job that challenges me, but I also don't have to deal with customers. Otherwise, a remote job is what I'm looking for. 

I know if I find a purpose, a goal to look forward to, and skills to improve upon that these anxious thoughts will go away. My mind wanders to dark places when it is idle.

title: Anxiety after eating in public
content:
hi! i was wondering if anyone else experiences this, since ive asked other people with anxiety and nobody has.

after eating anything sweet in public, whether a single piece of chocolate or an entire slice of cake, i feel extremely nauseous and nervous. at home, i can eat an entire bag of chocolate and feel completely fine (minus the normal stomachache youd get from that lol). i cant eat any sweets in public unless i know that im going home immediately after.

honestly, im nervous about eating in public at all. before i leave for classes, i dont eat, and i wont eat until i get home (which could mean im not eating until 3pm) because im too nervous to eat in public, outside of going to a restaurant. i think this may tie with my emetophobia, but im not sure.

does anyone else deal with this? if you do, do you have any tips on how you deal with this? im tired of missing out on fun treats with friends because of my anxiety of eating in public.

title: 20f with severe health anxiety
content:
I've been struggling with anxiety for as long as i can remember. i've had it so long to a point where i can't even fathom what a life without constant anxiety would even look like. throughout different points in my life, my anxiety has manifested in different ways. when i was a kid, i would just get super scared for no good reason and go cry to mom. in my adolescent years, id say up until age 17-18, it was mostly a feeling of impending doom. like everything was out of my control. just constantly overwhelmed even if i didn't have all that much going on. but for the last two years, every anxiety attack turns into me spiraling about my health. at first, it wasn't terrible and didn't happen too often. maybe like once or twice every two weeks. but these last six months, i kid you not, it's been happening AT LEAST 5 days a week. and let me tell you, im so fucking tired of it. 

two years ago, one of my closest friends that i've had since i was 11 years old got diagnosed with osteosarcoma cancer. for some context, her mother passed away of breast cancer over 10 years ago. before she passed, they learnt she had this gene called the TP53 mutation. if you're unfamiliar with what that is, it's basically a super rare gene that almost always inevitably leads to cancer. they didn't have these kinds of gene tests back in the day, so my friends mom had no way of knowing (until it was too late) that she'd be passing down that horror of a gene by having biological children. my friend beat the cancer in april of 2024 after one hell of a battle including countless surgeries that led her to be in a wheelchair. she was on the road to recovery, learning how to walk again and trying to resume back to her normal life until the cancer returned for a second time in november. same cancer, but way more aggressive. it's too dangerous to operate this time around, so she's been on the chemo pill. they're hoping it shrinks within the next few months so that it at least becomes safe to operate. and don't even get me started on her older sister who's also dealing with the same cancer for the second time as well after she also beat it the first time. it's nothing short of a nightmare of a situation for this family. 

anyways, when my friend got diagnosed the first time, i couldn't understand it. although the gene mutation was explanation enough, i still couldn't wrap my head around the fact that this girl who's been nothing but a kind, radiant soul her entire life somehow wound up living a life like this. a life where she's constantly fighting a battle against her own body. i thought, if it could happen to people like her and her sister who are two of the most genuine people i've ever met, why wouldn't it happen to me? even though i constantly remind myself that i don't have that gene or a history of cancer in my family and try to force my brain to understand the fact that the cards they were dealt were just extremely unlucky, i still can't help but spiral with every pain or weird feeling in my body ever since my friend was diagnosed the first time. 

for the past two years, while in the midsts of my panic attacks, i not only feel severely anxious, but also stupidly selfish. i always think, here i am in a healthy body with the luxury of living a normal life and yet i have the nerve to constantly stress over stuff like this, meanwhile my friend who i love so much is the one actually dealing with the shit i'm constantly afraid of. sometimes she'll ask me what's wrong, but i've never been able to tell her the truth. how can i? it would be so silly to say it to her of all people. i don't even know how id feel if i were in her shoes and someone without any health problems told me that shit. i just feel like such a terrible person constantly thinking of the worst when in reality, im perfectly fine and have the luxury of living a normal life when my friend doesn't. my brain just refuses to shut the fuck up. 

all that being said, i just want this to stop. i'm sick of constantly thinking im dying every night. im sick of spending my prime years spiraling over little pains that my brain practically gaslights my body into feeling. im sick of feeling this way when my fears are my friend's reality. it's exhausting and selfish of me. 

sorry for the long read, i just felt like some context was important to somewhat understand why i constantly feel this way. i'm desperate for a solution. if you have advice, an idea, or literally anything that could even be just potentially helpful, please let me know

title: [Need advice] Overwhelmed by job search anxiety
content:
I’m stuck in a cycle of anxiety around job applications and need help. I haven’t applied to a single job in months because I’m terrified of not knowing exactly what a role involves or how to handle the tasks. The fear of uncertainty and failure paralyzes me, and I keep imagining myself getting fired for underperforming.  

I worked in digital marketing before, and it went well because I had freelancing experience, so I knew what to expect. But with AI disrupting marketing, I want to transition to a business analyst role. The problem is, I don’t enjoy working with tools like SQL and Excel, which are often key parts of the job. I also tried getting into this field 5 years ago but failed at my first job due to underperformance (toxic work environment and memory issues due to low vitamin), and that failure still haunts me.  

I’ve spoken to therapists, but their advice hasn’t helped. I feel stuck and unsure how to move forward.  

If you’ve dealt with job application anxiety or fear of failure, how did you overcome it? I’d really appreciate any advice or tips. Please help.

Hi, my anxiety has been soo bad for way too long now. I have just recently come off of benzo's (lorazepam, oxazepam). title: Increase in anxiety with Wellbutrin
content:
Doc recently prescribed Wellbutrin. Within the first week I've noticed some very alarming things;

Heart palpitations that come out of nowhere (I nearly couldn't sleep last night because of it) and I've had moments where it feels like I'm having a panic attack or heart attack. Thank God I am resourced enough use certain tools like breathwork or meditation because otherwise it really could've spiraled!

Additionally, the RAGE I'm feeling in intense moments is completely foreign to me. I was in line earlier at a fast casual restaurant and the employees were taking sooo long to take my order. Maybe 7+ minutes, and no one else was in line, however I could see they were doing things that needed to be done - cooking, moving food, etc. Normal me would've shrugged this off, been pretty chill, maybe left, but *bupropion me*!?

Hell, my eyes could've spit daggers from them when the employee finally came to take my order! My chest was so tight and a ball of fury was swirling around down there, I didn't even want to speak to say what I wanted. I've almost never felt like this! It's truly concerning...

Can anyone else relate or have similar experiences? Did it get better for you? Should I stop right away?

title: Nervous about EVERYTHING and anticipatory anxiety
content:
Diagnosed with panic disorder

Backstory: So I've been struggling a lot the past months, I couldn't go to school or even to the store for a while. It's better now, but still bad. I can go out but school is really really hard, and I always have bad anxiety before going outside.

I've been struggling really bad with anticipatory anxiety, and many times that is what causes panic attacks. Before meetings with teachers or my therapist, I always feel like I'm gonna faint and I walk in circles from the moment I wake up until the meeting/event (even though I always do them online). Sometimes for days I feel like this, except for the few moments when I forget. The problem is that now I feel this way before doing the smallest things. I will use gaming as an example, because I game a lot. When I'm in the moment where I have to focus or do something that is 1v1 I get the same bad anxiety, and that's for such a small thing. Sometimes I get that feeling just by going to the kitchen if one of my family members are there. I guess I've always had anticipatory anxiety when I think about it, and that's the reason I've been having panic attacks before I realised that they were panic attacks (I only realised when they got so bad I ended up laying on a random buss stop crying and trying to breath, almost fainting). But I've always been a really open and social/curious person so I don't really know how that makes sense. Because of that I also feel like I've lost a part of myself. I just really want to be able to do the things I love, but I can't. How do I stop this? I'm nervous about absolutely EVERYTHING and I never try to avoid things because I know that will make it worse, but it still doesn't get better.

title: Just Will It Away!
content:
I need to rant because I am beyond exhausted with people who think you can just will your mental health issues away. You know the type—the ones who say, “Just go for a walk,” “Just breathe,” or the classic: “Pull yourself up by your bootstraps.”

If it were that simple, don’t you think I would’ve done it already? If I could magically cure my anxiety, depression, or trauma with a brisk jog or some yoga, I wouldn’t need therapy, medication, or years of unlearning the damage caused by abuse.

Trauma doesn’t just go away. It fundamentally changes you. I’m realizing more and more how deep the physiological impact of trauma really is. Complex PTSD isn’t just about “bad memories” or “feeling sad.” It rewires your nervous system, changes how your brain processes stress, affects your body on a hormonal level, and impacts everything from sleep to digestion to emotional regulation. This isn’t just a mindset problem—it’s a full-body experience, and the idea that I should just think my way out of it is beyond insulting.

And what’s worse? The condescension. The implication that I’m somehow choosing this, that I’m weak, lazy, or just “dwelling” on things. No, I’m not “stuck in the past.” The past is stuck in me. When you’ve lived through years of abuse, your brain doesn’t just snap back like a rubber band the moment you decide to “move on.” Healing isn’t linear. It’s complicated, exhausting, and requires real work—not just wishful thinking.

What makes it even worse is when the people who were supposed to protect you, love you, and be there for you were the ones who hurt you the most. When you grow up in emotional neglect or outright abuse, you don’t just get over that. How do you just “move on” from never feeling safe, from never having support, from having to parent yourself while the people around you acted like your suffering didn’t exist?

Some of us never had a safety net. We never had a support system. We never had people to turn to when things got bad. And then, on top of that, we’re expected to function like everyone else, as if all of that didn’t permanently alter our ability to trust, to connect, to feel okay in our own skin.

I’m tired of the oversimplification of mental health. I’m tired of people who have no idea what it’s like to live with CPTSD acting like they have all the answers. And I’m really tired of being made to feel like my struggles are my fault.

For those of you who deal with this, how do you respond? How do you handle people who refuse to understand the complexity of trauma and mental health? Because right now, I am struggling to stay patient.

Thanks for letting me vent. I just needed to get this off my chest.

title: Deathly afraid of developing psychosis/schizophrenia
content:
Hello, I am a 19 year old college student and I have been experiencing anxiety and on and off depression for the last year and a half. Lately, after learning about psychosis and schizophrenia in a psychology course, I have become terribly worried that I am in the beginning stages, or the prodromal phase of schizophrenia. Being 19, I am in the age range where schizophrenia usually develops, and ever since this fear has entered my head, it’s been making it difficult for me to sleep, concentrate, etc. Lately, every time I have a conversation with someone, I find myself ruminating about it and thinking about whether or not I was acting strange, talking weird, stuff like that. I’ve talked to a few people about this, and they’ve mentioned that it might be OCD, as I have had similar obsessions about different things in the past. But I just can’t help but worry. I also was a chronic weed user for the past year, (I have quit now) and that fact has further exacerbated my anxiety, due to learning that weed use can trigger schizophrenia or psychosis. Additionally, I sometimes get episodes of depersonalization/derealization which makes me think I am losing my mind even more. 

I’d like to hear what you guys think about this. Am I going crazy? Do I just have really bad anxiety or OCD? Any advice would be appreciated.
