title: DAE feel this way? is anxiety a 24 hour a day 7 days a week ordeal?
content: i legitimately am so mad at myself for saying “oh i have anxiety” back when i was only really feeling stressed. this is nothing like stress. this is debilitating. 24 hours a day 7 days a week i am in misery. the only time i get slight relief is when i am asleep and even then i wake up several times in the night. i am tired literally all the time. i have horrible dpdr symptoms, i feel like i cant enjoy anything anymore. i am not excited about the future of things like i used to be. i want to isolate myself i don’t even want to be around anyone. i have a CONSTANT sense of panic and dread in my chest, but with no physical symptoms? i am not short of breath, i’m not having chest pain or heart palpitations, i’m not shaky or sweating. it’s JUST in my head and a constant sense of panic. i sit and worry if i will ever be normal again. as if only 60% of my conscious is even present and the rest i feel suppressed. i am in a foggy cloud all day. i can barley finish my sentences it takes literal effort to have a conversation. i am so terrified i am going to lose my boyfriend who is the only person i genuinely care about anymore, because if he finds out i am this way he probably wouldn’t want anything to do with me. i feel like i am holding on by a thread. does anyone else have this? does anyone else feel this every single day all day and fears that they’re actually going f*** crazy?

title: How to get over fear of death
content: My biggest fear ever has always been death, I take 3 different medications, one for depression, adhd, and mood disorder. It messes with my mind big time but I’m always worried about dying. I don’t know why or how to get over this fear. But it’s haunting and I know that one of the reasons are because of some close family I’ve lost over the years (trauma) so if anybody has any tips it would be appreciated. It’s just hard going everyday worrying about what’s next.

title: I’m not sure how to communicate that I need help
content:
Trigger warning ⛔️

I have a history of anxiety, anxiety attacks, and depression. I had a complicated childhood and continue to have a strained relationship with my parents. I’ve been to therapy twice before. These sessions helped in short term, more like a bandaid to the larger problem. My mental and physical health have been slowly getting better over the past 5-6 years but I continued to struggle with anxiety attacks, sleep, self hate and (infrequent) sh. 

This summer I experienced a very stressful situation with my family in my safe space. Since then my life has derailed a lot. This summer I was exercising, eating healthy, sleeping better, loosing weight (I’m overweight) experiencing more of the world, feeling alive! The month after the event I gained 5-6kgs. Since then I’ve had really poor sleep, frequent anxiety attacks, flashbacks of the stressful event and been feeling more desperate with self hate. I’ve been engaging in more self destructive behaviors. I haven’t been able to upkeep my home and work life - my apartment is a mess and I’m working half of the time I’m supposed to. I feel like I cannot continue living like this. I feel I’m suffocating with all the things I need to do, despite feeling like I need to stop.

That is why I approached a therapist. We had a nice first chat where I opened up to her. The second time I saw her, she told me that I could use some CBT. Maybe I misunderstood her, but it seemed to me like she was suggesting that everyone has problems and I could get some basic help but she doesn’t think I need anything else for the time being. I really connected with her the first time so I felt that there was a disconnect between how I feel and how I come off. She said it didn’t seem like my mental health was impacting my life and work. I was told that it might seem like a crises to me (but it’s not compared to other people). 

I’m not really sure what to make of my experience with this situation. I feel demoralized and invalidated in my experience. At the same time, I’m trying to understand her response and reassess my “realities”. 

Looking for some support. Advice is very welcome.

title: Health symptoms went away after starting anxiety meds????
content:
I’ve had a lot of health symptoms that doctors can’t figure out. A handful of doctors say it’s anxiety. 

Has anyone had health issues (like actually physical symptoms) & once they started anxiety meds, the symptoms disappeared?! 

My symptoms:
-chronic fatigue
-chronic dizziness 
-wide spread inflammation/pain
-feeling sick all the time/malaise

title: Chronic nausea
content:
I’ve been experiencing chronic daily nausea for almost a year now. It varies in severity from being somewhat manageable to fully unbearable. I’ve been prescribed anti-nausea medication which helps somewhat and spend most of my day sucking on strong mints which also helps somewhat. I had an endoscopy which showed I have GERD and gastritis, so take omeprazole for that. But there are days this is utterly awful! I also have emetephobia which doesn’t help matters as this obviously increases my anxiety.
I do have anxiety and know there is a strong connection between anxiety and the stomach but the nausea can happen at random times even when not nauseous.
This started when I was taking fluoxetine and came off of it due to the nausea, but the nausea persisted. I feel helpless and a bit scared that this is my life now. I want to live my life and enjoy it and not be incapacitated by feeling so sick.

Thank you.

content: Hello! How can I cope with anxiety and maybe anxiousness before doing something? Especially working out with my trainer, we have a session once a week which has been fun and I’m comfortable workout with him, but I get this weird feeling the night before. How can I let go of this feeling it’s so weird.

title: Took myself to the hospital..
content: I had a severe panic attack at work today because I was very dizzy and then I felt a random sharp headache and got very scared and almost fainted because I was hyperventilating.. I was sure that it was a brain aneurysm so I called an ambulance… my blood pressure and heart rate were extremely high & they did blood work on me. The only thing that shows is that my white blood cell count is high because im fighting off an infection currently . They did do a CT scan everything looks normal I just have some fluid in my sinuses. They diagnosed me with sinusitis , which makes sense because I’ve been having facetal pressure, dizziness, mucus, and dry nasal passages. I was just so scared and went to the very extreme. I’ve never felt like that before, luckily all my nurses were super sweet, and a lot of them are struggle with anxiety themselves. They made me feel very comfortable and didn’t make me feel dumb for any of my questions. Meanwhile, my family is not as understanding and keep telling me I’m just being dramatic.. but I literally can’t help it. I had a cousin who passed away from my brain aneurysm two years ago while pregnant she was 19 years old She had hypertension… so anytime I feel something weird in my brain I go to the very worst. I feel a bit at ease now they gave me an Ativan to relieve my anxiety. It really helped!! TREMENDOUSLY.. I just wish I had someone in real life who understood me. My family says im mentally ill and that this isn’t normal .. 😕

title: Worst experience of my life.
content: I am 21 M and I take two medications at the moment, 20mg of Adderall for ADHD and 20mg of Propranolol for anxiety. I do general anxiety disorder but this time it was much different. So it all started when I got something that seemed related to my GERD, every now and then food I eat will get stuck at the end of my esophagus, causing a sharp pain at the center of my chest. I couldn’t get it to go away, and a little difficulty breathing but I’ve dealt with it before so I wasn’t so worried. I felt very off though (cold tired) so I checked my blood pressure. It said 156/100. Didn’t seem right so I checked it again, 178/110. Now I was really worried. Checked again as I called a nurse line, went to 200/130. Nurse said to call 911 so I did. In the ambulance my bp read at its most 237/130. All of sudden my entire chest felt on fire and then I felt the worst pain of my life in my head. I am normally a very reserved person and don’t speak up much but at that moment I was begging the EMS to make the pain stop. Long story short they did a CT scan on my head, two x-rays, a blood test, and of course an EKG. All came back normal. The ER doctor didn’t even want to put me on BP medication because she said I was stable and my baseline was  normal.Can someone tell me how this is possible? I genuinely thought I was either dying or had some sort of serious condition. I’ve had bad panic attacks before but this felt so different.

content: I am struggling with stress and anxiety management in my life and just quieting my mind in general. I am looking for a wellness retreat (based in US, but willing to travel anywhere) based around yoga and meditation. I would like to be somewhere with minimal pleasantries and preferably guided/rigorous schedule to keep me on track. Silent retreats would be ideal. Please send any suggestions :)

title: Moved to a new city, adopted a kitten and had the anxiety attack
content:
Hey there! The past three years have been really tough for me. Starting in September 2021 (I was 23), I had a panic attacks every day, and I started therapy, which helped a bit. But soon after, I began having obsessive thoughts about harming others or myself. I thought this might be a sign of schizophrenia, so I went to see a psychiatrist - actually, three different specialists to get varying opinions. They all said I had anxiety disorder with obsessive thoughts. I’m still working with a psychologist, and it’s been a bit of a rollercoaster. Some days are better, some are worse. I'm still thinking that my obsessive thoughts are the symptom of schizophrenia. On top of that, the war started in my country, and in the past few years, I’ve moved through five cities, two countries, and just a month ago, I moved to Toronto with my boyfriend, leaving my old life behind. We decided to adopt a kitten (I’ve never had a pet before), and we brought her home five days ago. I’ve been so anxious about potentially having those horrible obsessive thoughts again, especially about possibly causing harm to this little creature, that I ended up having a panic attack.

She’s so small and innocent, and every time she meows or seems scared, I feel like a terrible person. I worry that I can’t be a good cat owner, or that I should be happier than I am in this moment. She is perfect, beautiful and very smart cat. But adopting her wasn’t a random decision - I’ve dreamed of having a cat my whole life. I loved visiting friends with cats and even looked after them when they were on vacation. I have no issue with feeding her, cleaning the litter box, taking her to the vet - it's more about the emotional side of having a little animal who depends on me, and knowing I need to dedicate time to making her happy. So, I guess I’m just wondering what’s happening with me, and whether I’m a bad or a person with a serious mental disease because of these thoughts. Thank you so much for reading this, and sorry for the long message!

Please tell me that I'm not going crazy!:(

Is there anyone else who has the same thing or has a possible remedy for it? 

Breathing exercises don't work for me sadly and a benzodiazepine also doesn't fix it. HELP!
I'm so stuck and tired of this feeling.

content:

When I am with other people I kinda go back to reality and feel better, kinda relieved. 

Do you also experience it?

title: Blurry vision
content: Hii, i know when I’m getting blurry vision my anxiety is becoming a bit worse. Do other people also experience this symptom? And I always right away think that it is physical, low blood sugar or whatever or a disease. Anyone that can relate?

title: Does anyone else get anxiety from background noise??
content:
For as long as I can remember, I would get really weird anxiety from footsteps and people talking. Ill elaborate on this further.

For the footsteps it’s not like hearing people walking around in the mall or at school it’s more so if I’m in my room or in the bathroom or even just in a separate bedroom and I can hear people walking in the distance. 

People talking same thing with the footsteps if I’m in my own closed space and I can hear people talking outside of said space it gives me anxiety

I don’t know where this could have even rooted from because most of my weird anxiety, triggers and things are correlated to something whether it be childhood trauma, a bad experience, an ex partner etc. But I really don’t understand this walking and talking thing. 

I feel absolutely gut wrenched and I get almost nauseous and dizzy, and terrified. I feel my palms getting sweaty and my head spinning, even though it’s just footsteps and talking.  

Does anyone else feel like this? I’ve brought it up to so many of my friends and they all say they’ve never heard of anything like this. I just feel unheard lost and confused. I’m also just a little bit scared. I don’t know how to comfort myself when this is happening. Thank you for reading if you read all the way.

title: Worried i might have messed things up-is there still hope?
content:
Hey everyone,

I’ve been talking to a guy for about two weeks, and we’ve had some really great moments together. We met in person and really clicked, and we’ve talked about our future plans. But recently, I’ve been feeling anxious about whether I’m messing things up.

A couple of days ago, I started feeling like he was pulling away – he wasn’t replying as quickly, and I got more anxious. I tried to give him space, but I ended up texting him a bit too much when I was worried. I told him I felt like he was pulling away and that I was concerned, but now I’m wondering if I overdid it.

Before all of this, he had mentioned that he appreciated me communicating my feelings to him because it made it easier to talk. But now, he’s not texting as much, and I’m worried I’ve done something wrong or pushed him away. I really miss him and don’t want to ruin what we have.

Do you think I messed this up? Or is there still hope? How do I deal with this anxiety without overthinking and pushing him further away? I’m trying to stay calm, but it’s been tough.

Has anyone else been in a similar situation? Any advice on how to move forward without overthinking?

Thanks for the help.

title: If someone says something affectionate or tries to touch me while I'm eating, I feel sick. It's ruining my life.
content:
Please, If you have any idea of why this is happening or if you have a suggestion that might help me, please, do.

It's hard to say with precision when this problem started. Officially, the first time I felt this way was about 5 years ago, but my psychologist believes it has been a problem for longer than that — and that most likely, I reached my limit and started to feel the problem as intensely as possible, all that was missing was a trigger.

When I was 14 years old, I dated a girl during the pandemic. We didn't usually meet due to the circumstances and because of that, a part of our relationship was long distance. 3 months had gone by until we finally had the opportunity to see each other, I invited her to eat a burger at a relative's house and everything went well until the moment we sat down to eat. Everyone was sitting at the table and she was sitting next to me, I prepared my burger beforehand just the way I liked it to be done and I took the first bite. The feeling was immediate. I felt nauseous and dizzy, my body started to sweat and I felt that chill from when you lose something or someone important to you, it felt a lot like an anxiety attack, but it was much stronger. The last symptom was the urge to vomit, and I couldn't bear it. I ran to the bathroom and tried to calm myself down, and it was working until my girlfriend decided to check on me. As soon as she showed concern, it all came back. The situation was desperate. I was trying to relax, but her presence made it all come back and I had no idea what was happening. I think that I convinced her to leave me alone at that moment and I finally got to recover. The rest of the day felt like a blur, I felt exhausted and extremely weak without doing anything. I have never experienced anything like that in my entire life.

After that day, every time my girlfriend or someone from my daily life showed affection towards me, I felt the same way I felt that day. It was bearable in some way, but it turned out to be unbearable when someone tried to touch me. Any slight attempt to touch me felt like torture. When it happened, I felt paralyzed. I couldn't move a muscle, I was petrified with discomfort and I struggled to control my thoughts. Everything I mentioned, as I said, was tolerable, the worst part was the urge to puke. Both times it occured, I was in a relationship and those were the worst days of my life. All it takes is words of affection or an attempt to touch me and I get triggered, my body responds instantly. Even when I'm distracted and free of worries, my body responds the same way. Vomiting has always been the "highest stage" of this reaction, and it is the moment I completely lose control of my mind and mind. I always think I'm going to die and it's exhausting to live like this. Within the relationship, I was never able to be alone with her again, always scared by the thought of being touched and feeling sick because of it. The only moment I felt safe around her, was when we were surrounded by other people. I was sure she wouldn't touch me without permission or in a more "direct way".

It is important to make it clear that she was NEVER invasive and that she always RESPECTED my boundaries, these thoughts only went thought my head as a way of trying to explain what was happening to me. We broke up later and remained as friends. The interesting part is that the issue suddenly disappeared, just like magic. Of course, sometimes I felt sick because I wasn't completely free of it, but it wasn't nearly as intense as before.

Over the years, I learned to live with it. I avoided hugs, always said "I love you" before the person had the opportunity to say it first, ran away from family gatherings and adopted the image of a cold person to protect myself from any display of love and affection. It was tolerable for some time. Just like a virus, the issue began to "mutate" and affect even more areas of my life as the months gone by. Sometimes I had to stop talking to my friends and ask them for some time alone, because I couldn't stand the discomfort and the sickness. I could only stand the feeling when I was with my friend group and strangers, what was really bad was when my family and love interests were affectionately towards me. It was simply unbearable. I went to 4 psychologists before finding my current one, none of them paying attention to this dilemma. I went to my current psychologist only with the intention of resolving this issue, because it was staring to become difficult to live with such a problem. I made a lot of progress and I started to notice a few things. Whenever I felt bad, I was close to food. The first time it happened, I was eating, and every occurrence after that: I was eating, had just eaten, or was near food. If someone says something affectionate while I'm eating, I feel sick. It doesn't necessarily have to be an "I love you" or "you're beautiful", but what I understand as affection, which even involves jokes to make me laugh. As I said before, all of this is tolerable when it doesn't get out of hand, but when it affects my life to the point I can barely eat without feeling sick, it has become an urgency.

A long time ago, I changed several habits of mine because if it, such as having lunch with my family, being touched by my girlfriend when I'm eating, having snacks with friends and, most recently, I started to skip lunch. Somehow, the issue ended up affecting even things that don't directly envolve affection or being touched. Just the thought of lunch being an activity known for bringing a family together is enough to make me feel sick. Any conception and construction I have about what love is, and how it can be expressed, is enough to mess up my life. With some people, it's even harder to control, especially because of the proximity we share, but mainly because of the trust issues. The first thought that comes to my mind is: "if I ask this person to stop, will they respect my decision?". I built a hierarchy of trust in my head, from the most complicated to the simplest to deal with: love interests, family, friends and strangers. The funny thing is, how come my mind thinks a stranger is more trustworthy than a partner?

Because of this idea, my psychologist suggested that I might have suffered some kind of abuse during childhood. Not necessarily sexual violence, but a "simple" psychological abuse while I was eating, which expands the range of hypotheses. For example, I may have heard someone swearing at me during lunch and it created a trauma. The bif issue is that I don't remember basically anything from my childhood, not even my traumas. These days, I've been having some trouble swallowing pills and dealing with strong emotions, always around food. I don't know what to do or what to think about it anymore, I just want to be free from this issue and go back to living normally.

title: Found a small lump in neck that's only felt when stretching?
content:
Hey everyone,

I've recently noticed what feels like a small golf ball-sized lump on the back left side of my neck, just below the hairline. Here's what I've seen:

* The lump is NOT visible in the mirror
* Can ONLY feel it when stretching my neck to the right or at certain angles
* When my neck is in a normal position, I can't feel or see it at all
* No real pain or discomfort
* I've been spending a lot of time on computer work lately with less-than-ideal posture

I've done some research and came across information about muscle knots, which made me wonder if this could be related to my increased computer use and possible forward neck posture. However, I'm not entirely sure how muscle knots manifest or if they can cause lumps like this.

I know the standard advice is "see a doctor," and I agree! However, I'm currently uninsured, so I'm hoping to hear if anyone has experienced something similar, particularly in relation to poor posture or extensive computer use.

In the meantime, I've started doing neck stretches and posture exercises. Would love to hear your experiences.

title: Is Amytryptyline useful for anxiety? Specifically social anixety.
content: I have a doctor’s appointment tomorrow to talk about medication. Already taking it at a low dose for other reasons and I can’t take SSRI’s of SNRI’s.

title: Citalopram not working anymore all of sudden?
content:
Ive been using Citalopram for over 15 years (40mg/day). It always worked great, all of a sudden it no longer works, like snap of a finger. Now I'm going on and off with heavy anxiety attacks every \~7 days, with between where the anxious feeling is never away. This has been going on for 6 months now. Symptoms are:

* Pressure headaches, usually forehead.
* Tension and tingling sensation outer right eye/eyebrow.
* Lightheadedness and/or dizzy feeling.
* Constant tinnitus in right ear.
* Waves of goosebumps going all over my body including head.
* General anxious feeling in my stomach and legs.
* Uncontrollable shivering in extreme cases.
* Sensitive to light/sound.
* Trouble concentrating.
* Constantly tired. Short sleep spurts (3-4 hours max).
* Heart palpitations.

title: Breast cancer anxiety
content:
Sorry, this is a long post. I don't want to look at another Google page, so this is me looking for comfort.

Well, I (F43) guess I suffered from health anxiety from a very young age, but it's been okay for a really long time (even my family didn't notice).  Recently it's been getting really bad though. I was convinced I had a brain tumor or early onset Alzheimer's for almost a year, because my memory would be really bad at times. I still was functioning on a high cognitive level at work though and managed my household with 2 kids. So, I finally got an MRI a few months ago and that ruled out the tumor. I finally am getting over the fear of these horrible disease, even the Alzheimer's that isn't detectable in it's early form. 

I have been practicing DARE and it's techniques really help me. I also noticed my cycle has a huge influence and my hypothesis is that I'm in my perimenopause, which would also explain the memory lapses. As well as the fear!

My new thing is a pain I started having in my right breast. It lasted for a week or two and would sting. I was becoming more worried over time, but also told myself it was probably also hormones so wait till your period start. Well, my period started and the pain was gone. But I noticed there was a lump in the center of my breast, just below where the pain would be before. This lump feels large and long (not round, more like an oval disc) and I can feel it best when I lift my arm. 

Because of the memory issues I got B12 injections and I had to make a doctor's appointment to order new. I figured I would get a look at the lump, while I'm there and I told myself to not worry any longer if the doc told me it was fine. The anxiety was pretty manageable until the appointment, because I told myself I would take the reassurance if it was offered. So far, so good.

The doctor felt the lump but called it small (I feel like I feel it a lot better and it feels really big, but I wasn't putting my arm up while he felt it, stupid I know). And because I have no more symptoms like leakage or dents, and no family history of breast cancer, he wasn't worried. He told me that if it doesn't grow and there are no other symptoms, I don't have to come back for it. His guess was it was hormones related.

Well, I woke up the next morning (yesterday) in total anxiety mode. I took a shower and felt like the lump was twice it's size, but I realized it was just the same as yesterday. Because I felt like I had to fix this fear right away, I emailed my doctor telling him I would like to get a referral to the hospital for a proper exam anyway (they make an ultrasound or mammography at the hospital, but I need a referral). He hasn't responded (will probably do so tomorrow because they try in 2 days) and I've been checking my phone over and over again today, fearing he might deny me the exam. I was totally obsessed. I have a wonderful doctor who listens really good, so I don't know why he would do so, but still..

To top it off I looked up the waiting times for hospitals today and they are up to 16 days. That's way too long, so now I have anxiety over the amount of anxiety I'm going to have for the coming weeks, even if my doc says yes. Everywhere I read (I know google is hell, but I can't help myself) it says breast cancer grows really fast. So 16 days feels like it could make it all so bad it can't be treated anymore.

Health anxiety really sucks! The problem with health anxiety for me is that I live in a country where the GP doesn't order exams or check ups easily, and I need proper reassurance from such a check, before I can get to the 'acceptance of fear' fase. All programs start with 'if you have been properly looked at by a medical professional, you know you don't really have this issue you fear.' But what if you feel like you are not properly looked at?

I guess I will have to accept the fact that I might die from some disease that could have been detected earlier or could have been treatable. If I'm at that stage I'm finally at the End Boss Level of kicking my anxiety to the curb. 

Can anyone relate? Any guidance?

title: Beta blockers that don't cause hair loss?
content:
I have Propranolol. It works good for anxiety. But it makes me lose my hair. Do you know any calming beta blockers that are less likely to cause hair loss?  


Edit: I asked ChatGPT about it, here is the answer if anyone else is wondering about the question:

"Some beta-blockers have a lower risk of causing hair loss compared to others. Hair loss is a possible side effect of beta-blockers, but it is not very common. If you are concerned about hair loss, it may be worth discussing with your doctor the possibility of switching to a beta-blocker that has fewer reports of this side effect. Here are some options:

# 1. Beta-blockers with a lower risk of hair loss:

* **Nebivolol (e.g., Bystolic):** Nebivolol is a selective beta-blocker that may have milder side effects compared to non-selective beta-blockers like propranolol. It is often used for high blood pressure and has been reported to cause less hair loss.
* **Atenolol:** Atenolol is another selective beta-blocker that may have a lower risk of hair-related side effects than some others.
* **Bisoprolol:** Bisoprolol is also selective and could be an option if hair loss is a concern.

# 2. Beta-blockers with a higher risk of hair loss:

* **Propranolol:** Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker and is more commonly associated with hair loss as a side effect.
* **Metoprolol:** Although metoprolol is selective, some people have reported hair loss as a side effect.

# Why can beta-blockers cause hair loss?

Hair loss can occur because beta-blockers may affect the growth cycle of hair follicles, causing more follicles to enter the resting phase (telogen effluvium). This leads to temporary hair shedding rather than permanent loss.

\>Are those as calming as Propranolol?

It depends on the effect you are looking for, as different beta-blockers have slightly different profiles in how they work on the body. Here is a comparison of the calming properties of the beta-blockers we mentioned:

# 1. Propranolol – The Most Calming

* **Mechanism of action**: Propranolol is a **non-selective beta-blocker**, meaning it affects both beta-1 (heart) and beta-2 (lungs, blood vessels) receptors.
* **Calming effect**: Propranolol is often used to manage anxiety, especially performance anxiety, as it blocks the physical symptoms of stress (e.g., heart palpitations, tremors, and sweating).
* **Note**: It also crosses the blood-brain barrier, which contributes to its calming effect.

# 2. Nebivolol – Less Calming

* **Mechanism of action**: Nebivolol is a **selective beta-1 blocker**, meaning it primarily works on the heart and has minimal effects on beta-2 receptors.
* **Calming effect**: It is generally milder and less sedating than propranolol because it doesn’t affect the nervous system in the same way. However, it can help reduce physical symptoms of anxiety, though perhaps not as effectively as propranolol.

# 3. Atenolol – Less Calming

* **Mechanism of action**: Atenolol is also a **selective beta-1 blocker**.
* **Calming effect**: Atenolol has a weaker effect on the nervous system and does not cross the blood-brain barrier as easily as propranolol. This makes it less effective for managing anxiety-related symptoms.

# 4. Bisoprolol – Similar to Nebivolol and Atenolol

* **Mechanism of action**: Bisoprolol is also a **selective beta-1 blocker**.
* **Calming effect**: Its effect on anxiety is mild, similar to Nebivolol and Atenolol. It is effective at lowering heart rate but less “calming” in terms of affecting the central nervous system.

# Summary: How Calming Are They in Comparison?

* **Propranolol**: The most calming and the best choice for managing anxiety-related symptoms.
* **Nebivolol, Atenolol, Bisoprolol**: Less calming and primarily effective for heart-related symptoms (e.g., high blood pressure or palpitations) but less noticeable for anxiety.

"

title: Help shape the future of social and spiritual care in online communities [Moderator Approved]
content:
Hi r/Anxiety! 

Mental health is getting more and more discussion online these days…but what about spiritual health? We are a team of researchers studying professional spiritual care which deals with people’s needs for: **meaning and direction in life; self-worth and belonging to community; and loving and feeling loved.** So, this applies to everyone, whether you are spiritual, religious, atheist/agnostic, or anything else. Please take [this survey](https://mines.questionpro.com/spiritualcare) (\~10-20 minutes) and tell us what you think about the best way to design online communities.

The link includes more detail, but here’s a summary of the main details:

Principal Investigator: Professor Estelle Smith ([u/c\_estelle](https://www.reddit.com/user/c_estelle)), Director of the HappyPlace Research Lab ([r/happyplacelab/](https://www.reddit.com/r/happyplacelab/)). 

Affiliation: Colorado School of Mines, Department of Computer Science 

Target group: Anyone who has ever visited r/Anxiety, including lurkers, active and inactive posters or commenters, and moderators or admins.

Compensation: Drawing 20 participants who complete the survey and provide a valid email address will be randomly selected to receive a $20 Amazon eGift Card.

Link: [https://mines.questionpro.com/spiritualcare](https://mines.questionpro.com/spiritualcare) 

Background: Millions of people now seek support for physical, mental, and spiritual health concerns through online communities, such as those here on Reddit. Our study aims to improve access to evidence-based care using insights from users like you.

title: Need advice/help

title: People trying to be my therapist
content:
Part of why I feel like "people suck" or "I hate people" right now is because they're trying to be my therapist despite me saying I'm in therapy. Or they don't give me space in terms of my anxiety.

I've been telling drivers through the medical transport that I have driving anxiety partly to get use to telling people. Then a Lyft driver (outsourced by the medical transport) taking me to therapy asked if I've had an accident. After I said I have anxiety for other stuff and the anxiety got worse from a D&D player wrongfully blowing up on me the week before, the driver said he noticed a pattern and that I need to not worry about what other people are doing (like a driver in the car) and should try immersive therapy like if I was scared of spiders, I should go in a tub of 100 spiders to see they're not hurting me and get over my fear.

Then an old coworker from over a decade responded to my Facebook post about having sat in the same seat as me at a tea place. She then messaged me asking how I was doing. I said I had anxiety and was unpacking a lot in therapy. She then asked if I knew the root of my anxiety, which she figured out for herself. I said I had critical parents but also had life events and how that person blowing up made it worse recently, but I had recovered from the blow up. She then asked why that person blew up on me. I told her and started feeling not okay from all my anxiety source talk. 

Her: Ooooo.

Her: I'll say more after I get out of work.

Me: I'm not able to talk about it a lot btw.

Then she sent 4 messages after 10PM. I haven't looked at it, especially because I've stepped away from Facebook this week and announced (and had given a heads up post about it) on there I was logging in just for events. But the messages preview showed "Sounds like drama for drama's sake. Best n..."

Y'all get people nosey or trying to be your therapist? I need to find a way to say to people "I have anxiety and am working on it. That's how I'm doing, but that's not an invite to discuss it or be my therapist, which I already have and am working with."


Edit: Fixed some missing words.

title: Anxiety attacks when remembering certain events
content:
Tbh, I don't even know what to call it. It's like anxiety attack symptoms: increased heart rate, feeling cold or shivering, brain fog, mixed with a headache, nausea, and cold hands and feet—all mixed with anger.  
I don't know why I've been having these feelings whenever I remember certain events that happened almost 10 years ago! I feel like there was some kind of block to the point that I totally forgot about these things and went on with my life. But lately, I've been having memories about some people I thought I had forgiven a long time ago. They're no longer part of my life now, but I never forgot what they did to me during the "BIG EVENT."

Lately, I've been remembering details, as if I were reliving those moments again. I feel angry, and I remember the anger I held back then—how I used to hold it inside to the point of getting headaches and migraines. I don’t know why I keep having these memories unexpectedly.

I always to be busy, I work , exercise, develop a skill or a hobby, or even watch something, i'm trying as much as I can to suppress these memories and i never really felt like they've been  bugging me that much, i used to think that I've always been looking forward and never look back mindset. but I think it's coming to bite me in the most unexpected time

I want to improve myself and I'm digging deep into myself to try and heal my inner child and core wounds too. These days I feel like I just wanna disappear. 

How do you deal with overwhelming situations, moments? What helps you calm your mind? Or I should just sit with these things and eventually they'll pass?

title: Living in Survival Mode is Exhausting
content:
I find it really hard to feel safe around people. A few close friends are exceptions, but even with them, I don’t fully let my guard down. It’s not just in my head. I physically feel my heart racing when I have to speak up, and my awareness is always in threat mode, even though I know there’s no real danger.

Before, I was only told I have ADD and Chronic Fatigue because I space out a lot and struggle to function. But I saw a therapist for the first time a few months ago, and he said he thinks it's some type of trauma and explained how it connects to ADD/ADHD. That actually made sense. Spending most of my life on edge has left me constantly exhausted and unable to think clearly or focus.

It’s frustrating because I know I have so much more to offer to myself and to others. I’ve been doing the exercises my therapist gave me, like sitting with and listening to those feelings without judgment or expectations, and while they help a little, they’re not the solution I hoped for, and really do nothing for me in the moment besides helping me get out of that state a bit quicker. I’m 22 (M) and have never had a truly intimate relationship. It’s not because I haven’t had chances. I’m not conventionally unattractive and stay in good shape, I just can’t let myself get close to people. Even making eye contact for more than a couple seconds takes enormous effort and feels like a struggle.

I just had an interview with a graduate program I really want to get into, and fumbled it because I was so physically on edge that my mind was fully blank, the questions came up and I literally had nothing to say. I know this probably sounds like a common and cliché issue, and maybe it is, but after years of trying to think my way out of it, it's beginning to feel like a dead end.

Not looking for magical solutions, since I doubt there are any, but had to get it off my chest, at least to someone (no friends or family know this about me and I cant bring myself to share it with them).

title: Severe overwhelming thoughts with physical symptoms - How do I stop it!
content:
Hi everyone, I’m a 24-year-old male, and I’ve been dealing with depression and racing thoughts since I was 17. Recently, things have gotten worse to the point where I'm feeling genuinely scared I might have an attack.

I’ve seen doctors, had an ECG and echo, and they’ve all come back normal, which helps with some reassurance, but the mental aspect feels overwhelming. For the past week, my mind has been consumed by intrusive thoughts, often about things happening in the world or even in my family that don’t directly relate to me. Even when I try not to think about them, these thoughts pop up and I can't stop them.

These thoughts have been making me feel physical symptoms, like left arm pain and chest pain, and it’s scaring me even more. I keep thinking that this stress might lead to something serious, especially after hearing about how stress can affect your health and potentially cause a heart attack. I’m also worried about my cortisol levels being elevated and causing damage over time. The feelings in my chest and mind are like as if I went through a breakup or something major happened that caused me some great shock. I get immense anxiety and sadness from all this and I experience constant emotional pain in my chest and left arm. 

I don’t have any previous health problems, but I’m terrified that this constant worry will eventually lead to something worse like an attack or arrest. Does anyone else here experience anything similar? How do you cope with these racing, intrusive thoughts and the fear they might trigger physical problems? Any advice on managing this would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance!

title: Does this sound like anxiety?
content:
I have been struggling really bad with anxiety the past few months, but it’s been getting better. However, I keep experiencing this feeling that I am pretty sure is just anxiety, but I want to make sure it’s not something I should get checked out. 

I will randomly get a racing heart, feel faint, start to feel like things aren’t real, I get worried about passing out, occasionally get tunnel vision, start to experience weakness in my arms and legs, and feel like I cannot relax. I’ve realized that these episodes usually happen when I am anticipating something, like going out in public, having friends over, or thinking about something I have to do later. I also feel like my mind is buzzing and it’s harder to think. The feeling does go away after a while and I am able to calm down. The thing that scares me the most about this feeling is the overwhelming sense of fear/dread and the fact that I start to dissociate a little bit. If it was a health problem, like a heart issue, would it come with all of these other symptoms? Does anyone else get anticipatory anxiety and feel this way?

Could it all just be anxiety?

title: How are they abused!?
content: I’ve had anxiety symptoms for a few years and didn’t know it was anxiety until I ended up in the ER. It was the worst experience going from doctor to doctor trying to get medication even after the ER discharged me with papers that suggested I be on anxiety meds. Fast forward A WHOLE EXTRA 2 YEARS of me still struggling with symptoms and only able to find self remedies to help, and I was finally able to attain some type of medication. However it’s through a family member who was able to get it prescribed for her even though she has no anxiety ! She knew of my struggle and gave them to me. It’s .25 alprazolam, and I don’t take it daily just on my hardest days because I don’t know if they will always be accessible. Somedays, just knowing that I have them helps me relax. And so my question is, how can people abuse it, I’m sure it’s at higher dosages, but I just feel so normal when I take it! No haze, no type of dizziness, and best, no more symptoms! I just feel like a normal girl being a part of society and going about her day. So how does it have such a bad wrap. Was this something that was a problem back in the day because doctors didn’t know how to prescribe it and gave it at higher dosages not know the long term symptoms of addiction? Or do people really take these low dose pills and just take like a lot to get high!? How did they ruin this for people that actually need it !?

title: On Cymbalta, Can’t Orgasm

It basically feels like I am going to orgasm, but I’m numb and sensitive all at the same time. Or like when you need to sneeze and you can’t lol. Doesn’t matter what assistance I have, it is frustrating.

title: Quetiapine
content: I've been prescribed 25mg quetiapine for anxiety. I'm meant to take one a day, in the evening. I'm quite concerned about taking it every day, I don't want to be dependant on it and I'm worried about some of the side effects. title: Suffering from hyperventilation? Try staring at bright light.
content: I've been having anxiety-based hyperventilation for mysterious reasons for the past week or so. During one such attack in my dark room I realized I had the fundamental need to escape to somewhere that had more light, like the dark was making it harder to breathe. We had recently installed some very bright white lights in a wall sconce on a dimmer switch and I thought "well hell, if a little light is good, maybe a lot of light is better" so I turned 'em up to max and stared into them. Sure enough my breathing normalized fairly quickly. I've done it a few times now and, like all things, who knows if it works, or who knows if it's a distraction that makes things better at the speed of normal recovery, but I wanted to share it with anyone who might need it here in these dark days.

title: Started Lexapro 3 weeks ago.
content:
I’ve struggled with anxiety and depression for years, and despite going to therapy for a long time and making significant changes in my life, I’ve always felt down for no apparent reason. Even when things were going well, I couldn’t shake the feeling of being stuck. I’m also naturally very anxious about almost everything, my roommate tells me sometimes I am sort of like a Chihuahua lol, also my ex told me this.

About a month ago, while I was in Vietnam, I started experiencing panic attacks, last time I got them was about 10 years ago. I went to see a psychiatrist in Hanoi, who prescribed me Clonazepam and Lexapro (and a few other things). At the time, I didn’t question it since I was in the middle of a panic episode and needed something to manage it, especially since I had a 12-hour flight back to the EU which was impossible without meds.

I had been considering seeing a psychiatrist for a few years now because I’d run out of ideas on how to improve my mental well-being and tended to auto-medicate with Alcohol which is terrible. In hindsight, those panic attacks turned out to be a blessing in disguise. After just three weeks on medication, I feel like a version of myself I didn’t know existed. I’m accomplishing things that would normally take me months: I enrolled in a German course (even though I’ve lived here for a while and only know the basics), earned a tech certification in just a week, and I wake up with real motivation to get work done. The motivation for the gym has dropped a little, but I’m still going.

That said, I stumbled upon this subreddit today and started to feel a bit anxious about the medication. I wondered if this treatment would eventually normalize my brain to the point where I could stop taking meds. Some people seem to stay on them for years, and I was concerned after reading about withdrawal experiences. But after reflecting on how much better I’ve been feeling these past three weeks, I’m choosing to focus on the positives. I’ll continue with my treatment, and once I find a new doctor, I plan to discuss my options further. As of now it has been life changing honestly.

title: Anxiety after illness. Coping and how long?

But after my illness, and some psychological evaluations, it seems I've been hit by a pretty heavy burst of anxiety, or as I see it, a mild depression of sorts. And I'm usually a very easily self motivated individual, and while there's a very good chance for my recovery to be quick, given that this is very recent and my experience according to my psychologist is likely just my body being chemically imbalanced and a mattwler of time. Coping with anxiety which to me had manifested like the nigh inability or want to do anything, I feel paralyzed at times unless I'm almost dragged to do things (like work). I only ever feel the will to do things in groups and it becomes difficult even then.

title: How do I know it’s just anxiety and not my Heart???
content:
I have been dealing with prolonged anxiety since about October, when I finally went to the doctor. Chest pains, rapid heart rate, “impending doom” you name it. 

I’ve had numerous EKG’s, got put on blood pressure medicine, echocardiogram, blood tests… everything was said to look normal or good. 

I got scared in the first blood test because LDL and HDL #’s were wayyyy out of whack and that is when I started feeling chest discomfort which they followed up with the echocardiogram at my request.

A little above 60% EF in the heart said it looked great, had x rays done to make sure there were no brain issues or lung issues. 

I’m still dealing with the anxiety all these months later and I’ve convinced myself something is wrong when I get too active. 

Is this just my anxiety making me feel this way? The doctor and a physical therapist both told me that my anxiety is probably making me have crazy muscle tension on my left side including my back which is probably the reason for the chest pains. 

Anytime my HR goes up when I’m working (physical labor) during the day I get a weird feeling. It’s not all the time but sometimes. I’ve also noticed when I’m nervous or anxious about something it spikes up too. 

I’m 35 Male that is overweight. I have lost around 50 pounds since that Doctor’s visit in October, completely quit drinking coke and only drink water with the occasional Gatorade. Eating healthier and feeling better physically because of it. 

It just freaks me out because I didn’t have any of this before and now all of a sudden I’m experiencing it pretty heavy. 

The anxiety is doing better but I didn’t know if anyone had any similar experiences. I noticed my panic attacks are way down from when this first started and I’m dealing with the oncoming attacks better by some things my therapist has explained to me. 

I thought my anxiety would be over since every test result has come back and says nothing is wrong but I’m still concerned about something being wrong. Is this normal? And how long does it last?? I’m doing my best and have actually stopped taking Clonazepam as much as I was. 

Instead of twice a day I have started cutting the pill in half and use it usually once a day, mainly before bed time when my anxiety usually ramps up for some reason. 

Any reassuring words or advice would be greatly appreciated.

title: I have a strange relationship with Xanax
content:
I'm in a remote part of Africa right now, and I got some Xanax over-the-counter to take for my anxiety. It’s easily available from pharmacies without a prescription. I've been having issues sleeping, and when I do get some sleep, usually just a few hours, when I wake up I start to panic. And so, I thought this medication could potentially help me out, even though I have never taken it. I'm also a little hesitant to take it because I don't know how I would react to it, and if I were to have an adverse reaction, or God forbid, some type of medical emergency, I would not get proper care here even though it's a very low dosage, and there's very little chance of anything major happening to me. 

Either way, I keep it with me at all times just in case my symptoms become unmanageable. I've become really emotionally reliant on having access to this medication though. So anytime I go somewhere, especially if I'm going out to the town, or going places where I'm not very familiar with, I take it with me just as a backup because I have experienced a little bit of panicky feelings when I go outside. I noticed that when I lose the medication or misplace it, I literally start to freak out. My legs start to shake, and I get the gut-punching feelings in my stomach. Once I find the medication, the symptoms resolve. Again, I haven’t taken it so there’s no mental reference point for me to say it’s actually helpful but I guess I get comfort from knowing that I have a powerful option should I need it. I have not reached the threshold yet because I’ve been able to manage my anxiety through sleep, breathing techniques and exercise. 

Long story short, I’ve become emotionally dependent on having Xanax with me (panicking whenever I can’t find it) even though I’ve never taken it. It brings me comfort knowing I have a safety net if my symptoms become unmanageable. It’s strange, I know, but it just shows that I probably have a lot of underlying anxiety issues that aren’t just about the Xanax itself.

title: My brain doesn’t know how to exist in stability, and it’s sabotaging me. Need advice.
content:
So I’ve realized something about myself, I don’t know how to function when things are stable because I’ve always had an unstable childhood. My mom being a sociopath, dad passing away, sister passing away from suicide. I’ve grown up constantly anticipating the next disaster, always staying one step ahead to avoid pain, and now that my life is actually stable, my brain is losing it.

I have a remote job, I live alone, and everything should feel fine. But instead of enjoying it, I feel like I’m self-sabotaging. I keep messing up at work every week, and deep down, I think it’s because my brain expects something bad to happen. It’s waiting for the other shoe to drop, so it’s like I’m unconsciously making it drop first.

It’s like this everything, a job, relationship, and thing. For example, with job, I’ve been constantly refreshing LinkedIn, deactivated it, then reactivated it, then deactivated again, because my brain is telling me to start looking for a new job now just in case I get laid off. Even though there’s no real sign that I will, my mind just won’t shut up about it. It’s like I can’t sit still because if I’m not preparing for disaster, I feel unsafe. The same was with my past relationship, like I already prepared myself that this wouldn’t last just by looking at the signs so I can just be one step ahead every time. 

I don’t even enjoy what I’ve accomplished because I’m already thinking about what’s next, how to stay ahead, how to make sure I never have to deal with inconveniences. Like, instead of just feeling okay in my job, I’m obsessing over what if I get laid off? and trying to control a future that hasn’t even happened.

Has anyone else felt this? How do you actually learn to trust stability when your brain has only ever known chaos? How do you stop yourself from constantly needing to be one step ahead? Because I feel like I’m ruining my own peace without even meaning to.

title: For anyone who needs to see this: yes, quitting vaping actually did help my anxiety.
content: I quit vaping like 20 days ago after dealing with intense chronic anxiety, OCD, panic attacks, and PTSD for majority of the past few years. While those issues still exist outside of my vaping addiction, quitting vaping and nicotine has made my medication much more effective, and it is SO much easier to avoid anxious thoughts. I know what it’s like the be addicted, hell I still am, so it’s okay if you’re not ready and quitting isn’t what you need right now. However, if you’re thinking about it, just know that it has helped my anxiety TREMENDOUSLY and I can’t picture a world in which I go back.

title: Systemic disregard of anxiety conditions by legal agencies
content:
I’ve struggled with OCD, anxiety, depression, and knee injuries requiring multiple surgeries since childhood. After a college knee injury and surgery, my mental health worsened, and my OCD became unbearable. I graduated in 2016, worked briefly as a teacher, but left due to worsening symptoms. In 2017, I was accepted into grad school but postponed enrollment to care for my father, who passed away from cancer later that year. Despite worsening knee pain, I delayed treatment to prioritize his care. After his passing, I had my third surgery in December 2017. During recovery, a severe bike accident during physical therapy led to a fourth surgery, disrupting my plans for grad school. That summer, I was bedridden and in the worst sustained pain of my life. I informed the University about the surgery, told them I would arrive late, and asked for help catching up, but received no response. For two months, I was on crutches, wearing a brace, and struggled with moving to a new apartment and school in a new state. Knee pain and instability persisted, leaving me increasingly behind."

My OCD and depression became unbearable every time I tried to study. Grad school coursework builds on concepts from the last years of college, but those years were extremely traumatic for me. Studying turned into reliving past trauma, leaving me depressed and exhausted. I sought help from the University mental health center, but they only offered one 30-minute therapy session per month, which wasn’t enough. I also tried connecting with other grad students to work in groups, as group work helps ease my OCD symptoms, but those efforts were unsuccessful.

"I registered with the campus disability center and requested accommodations for extra time on assignments, but my request was ignored, and I was dismissed from the program. I appealed, providing medical records of my surgeries, mental health struggles, frequent illnesses likely caused by medication prescribed by a university doctor, and records of hospital visits, physical therapy, and orthopedic consultations for ongoing knee issues. Despite this, my appeal was denied, likely because a professor falsely claimed I had never submitted any assignments.

I returned home in mid-2019 broken and inconsolable. Feeling mistreated, I spent months trying to make sense of my removal and compose a complaint, but my OCD made the process excruciating. Revisiting the events triggered extreme depression, leaving me unable to function. The process drove me to suicidal thoughts, forcing me to take it slowly. Eventually, after several months, I completed the complaint and filed it with the Office for Civil Rights.

**Filing with OCR**  
I filed a complaint with OCR, explaining that my five-month delay was due to disability-related reasons. I provided detailed documentation of my medical conditions, surgeries, and mental health struggles, along with expert testimony on the incapacitating effects of my OCD. According to OCR’s manual, exceptions for lateness are allowed in such cases, but despite waiting two years, they rejected my case as “too late.” They refused to explain why they ignored the exception and offered no further justification, mirroring the same disregard shown by my university.

**Turning to the U.S. Attorney’s Office**  
Following advice from a disability advocacy group, I filed a complaint with the U.S. Attorney’s Office. They claimed their denial was unrelated to the lateness or complexity of my case but refused to provide a specific reason, citing resource limitations. I suggested narrowing my case and using existing documentation to reduce their workload, but they still declined. They never asked how my condition impacted my academic performance or the timeliness of my actions, making their response feel like systemic disregard rather than a genuine resource issue.

**What I Need Help With**  
I feel systematically dismissed by these institutions, which seem to use pretexts to avoid taking my case. I suspect they don’t view my conditions as true disabilities, which in itself is a form of discrimination. With significant prosecutorial discretion, these agencies can decide which complaints to pursue, and their decisions are nearly impossible to challenge.

I’ve also reached out to my Congressman and Senators’ offices for advocacy, but they seem to lack understanding or interest, leaving me with no progress. Has anyone had positive outcomes engaging with lawmakers in cases like this?

I’m seeking advice on:

1. **Disability discrimination cases** – Is this pattern of rejection common, and how can I hold these institutions accountable?
2. **Advocacy efforts** – How can I better advocate for myself or find someone to champion my case?
3. **Systemic issues** – Are there organizations tackling systemic disregard for disabilities in education and legal systems?

Any guidance would mean a lot. I’m at a loss for how to ensure my disabilities are taken seriously.  
Thank you for your support.

title: I give up on overcoming dental phobia
content:
I give up.

I don't know if this is progress or harmful, but I do not care. I am done. I have spent the last ten years of my life fighting dental anxiety. I went back to the dentist for the first time in years at twelve and it started out manageable but then a couple bad experiences combined with other traumas and my own personality drove it up the wall. I haven't been in four years. I have spent those years obsessing over any sensation in my teeth, searching the Internet, talking to people about dentists, and guilt-tripping myself and shaming myself and desperately trying to force myself to go.

I give up. Pre-gap, I canceled appointments before because I was throwing up in the car midway through a panic attack. I spent an entire vacation obsessing over the location of dentist's offices. I've done DIY exposure therapy multiple times. I had the world's greatest dentist - still nothing. No trust, no tolerance. Not only did I leave the office sobbing hysterically, but I sprinted half a mile away in full fight-or-flight mode.

This entire time I've been trying to live up to my own (and my parents') standards. Just go to the dentist. Just go to the dentist. Stop being such a baby, grow up and go to the dentist. Everyone does it. Get over it. Get over yourself.

Yeah, well, I give up. I found a new dentist with amazing reviews who does sedation dentistry for anxious patients. Next time I sit in the dental chair to get work done, I am doing it with an IV in my arm. I am going to make an appointment for an exam, see what I need, and then ask the dentist to schedule a time to knock me out and get it done. No more lying in the chair trembling violently, too afraid to speak, dissociating so heavily I am watching myself from above. No more crying myself to sleep, no more sleepless nights. What am I even trying to prove? Why is it so important to me that I can overcome my fear of the dentist? What, am I supposed to be a better person because I can sit through a root canal?

No. Screw that. Knock me the f\*ck out and spare me the suffering. Dental phobia, you win this round, but you don't get to mess with the rest of my life. I'm not any less of a man because my nervous system's got a thing about dentists, and I am done listening to people who say I am.

title: Scared of dying in my sleep
content: I’ve been having a weird tingling in my feet ever since my anxiety spiked a few days ago, i looked it up and it says online that i have circulation issues or some sort of organ failure. I’ve had testing done in the last year or so and I’m perfectly healthy, but my brain just won’t accept that’s it’s just anxiety. Every night before I go to sleep I have really awful panic attacks even though I’m on medication because I’m scared I’ll die in my sleep. I always feel dizzy and get heart palpitations. It’s happening again tonight and I’m super light headed. I accidentally had a drink with caffeine without realizing and now I’m shaking and panicking all over again. Does anybody else have this fear or the tingling sensation?

title: Does anyone have a tickly feeling in their brain?
content:
Hi all. Sometimes when I feel a bit like things are not 'happening for me in life', like stagnant, boring stuck, etc. And then maybe I am a bit stressed or I have to meet people who are more bubbly, or where I have to perform or anything that causes even more stress, I get this tickly weird feeling in my brain. 

It feels like it's coming from the front of my forehead, but also feels like pressure on the sides near my ears, things get a bit blurry and I feel at a distance from things. It feels like intense brain fog but the tickly crawly spike feeling in my head is a strong sensation. 

Sometimes I also feel fatigue in my body like I'm very tired, and sometimes when I am having dinner with this sensation, I feel my mouth and lips vibrating after eating, but this may not be related. 

Do you know what this is, it's really annoying!!

Don’t want to stay at my current job forever. Which feels like my mom gets mad, as my dad did his whole career at. He was union. I’m a white collar worker. Dating is just awful. I feel lonely. Nothing excites me anymore. My friends listen offer advice, while parents don’t want to hear it. I say I’m exhausted of long commutes even though I’m only in office 2 days a week now. title: Anxious About Not Being Able To Sleep
content:
Hi Everyone,

For the past about 2 weeks or so, I’ve only been getting around 4-5 hours of sleep during the week. I’ll wake up around 4-5am and just can’t go back to sleep. 

The weekends I get around 7-8 usually but I’m worried that the lack of sleep during the week is going to cause health issues, which is making it even harder to sleep. I have a destination wedding I am at right now so I think that’s what’s causing the anticipation anxiety because I have to give a speech. 

Any tips for sleep anxiety? Or any stories that people can share that may help ease my mind a bit. I’m kind of freaking out. Thanks

title: Eye pain worries
content: Hi so I woke up one night in November with really bad eye pain behind my left eye. I managed to go back asleep and by the morning it had gone. In December it repeated itself but stayed for around 3 days and then started slowly disappearing. However since then my eye pain has not gone away. Each day it’s either manageable or really bad but it’s never gone. I’ve been the doctors and I’ve just had an eye test. My doctor is suggesting migraines and my eye test was fine. I had a MRI scan last year in June for other reasons so I know my GP won’t give me another but the pain is really bad. It feels like someone is pushing my eyeball out from the inside and then I will get random shooting pains in it too. I read an unruptured aneurysm can present behind your left eye and now I’m worried sick. No double vision or anything but this daily pain. Also none stop twitching of the eye. Surely it’s not normal for this long? Anyone else?

title: Too Anxious to Live
content:
First time poster, so feel free to correct my formatting.

I’m dissatisfied where I am in life (yet grateful): am 24, mentally ill, was partially coddled, no job or money or friends, been living in someone’s (a family friend) house for 4 years now. There’s no opportunity for me to thrive or develop. I want to start my adult life and be the man I want to be by getting away from my old life. 
“Then just move if you’re so unhappy!”
But I live in the middle of nowhere (population ~1,000 people) and don’t have the ability to get my license. I CAN drive, but not publicly due to a fear of laws, cops and other drivers, and navigating through the city. So I’ve come to the conclusion that I just might not have the ability to drive and I’m sure I can figure out the transit system and can literally walk anywhere that I need to get to. Getting a job would be hard to get since some businesses require it for insurance too. 
I know that everything I want/need is outside of my bubbled town but I just don’t have the ability to leave it. It’s slowly driving me crazy (and will admit have done terrible things to stay sated) due to outliving my expectations since I’ve been suicidal since childhood and the only thing that saved me was going to high school outside of my community and being able to discover my true self. 

Hell, I’ve tried running away a couple years ago (as an adult) but was ratted out by my community members to my Mom who found and brought me back. Realized I’ve never told her how much I loathe staying here, since everyone around me thinks I just love it (which I do, just hate the people here). Probably because I keep my feelings to myself, as I don’t trust them with other people, especially my family. 

I’ve tried therapy in the past to get better but it never worked/stayed consistent, due to not being able to get to the sessions and my poor communication skills. Did try some meds but didn’t work for me either. 
So I’m at a loss as to what to do to improve myself enough to gain a happier life. 

Yet now what? Being too afraid to even start a life. There are so many factors that make up my struggles that it would be a long, sad and pathetic rant. Maybe it’s just me being at a loss at what to do. 
I’d appreciate the advice and if you need more context just let me know.

title: Update on my brain zaps
content:
Quit taking Sertraline two weeks ago after taking it for two years.   Tapered according to doctors instruction. 

Man,  I thought I had it bad a couple days ago.   It's gotten a bit worse.   The dizziness that comes with it has made it hard to function normally.   It's also brought on a bit of withdrawal anxiety and depression.  I binned some Counting Crows and couldn't do crying this morning after being up all night just wanting to go to sleep.  I'm still holding on hope that this is the worst of it and I'll start seeing the improvements over the next few days.   

Stopping these drugs is no joke.

title: Which SSRI to avoid sexual problems?
content:
My (25M) doctor has asked me to choose one, I already have a temporary muscle issue which gives me ED, so I want to add to that as little as possible.

I’m in the UK so Wellbutrin or Viibryd is a no-go, and I think I’d have to cage fight someone for access to vortioxetine. I’m looking at:

prozac (fluoxetine)
zoloft (sertraline)
Celexa (citalopram)
Lexapro (escitalopram)

Any worsening of ED is what I want to avoid, if it takes me an hour to get off I’m willing to put up with that. Any advice is appreciated!

title: Political FOMO Anxiety
content:
So I am the Black Sheep of my family so my politics are very different from those in the rest of my family. Because of this I feel extreme anxiety about wanting to always be on top of the news. I'm obsessively reading and looking for what's happening so that my family can't catch me off guard with something.

Logically I know that it's impossible to know all the news and I'm exhausting myself trying to keep up. So I guess the discussion here is how much is too much? How do I signal to my brain that it's okay to not be consumed by the news cycle?

Any anxiety relief tips on this would be appreciated.

title: Self doubt in boxing - comparison, doubt
content:
I’ve been boxing for a few years and have had around 6-7 competitive bouts. I stopped competing a couple years ago pre covid and have kept myself fit but now looking to get back into it. 
I’ve decided to join another amateur boxing gym but I can’t help but have this common theme of comparing myself to others in the gym. If there’s someone that’s relatively a new guy or a beginner or has ‘faults’ in his shadowboxing I always thinking to myself “I’m not worried” but if I see someone who looks sharp I just doubt myself and cannot be myself when around them as I subconsciously put them on a pedestal.

Iknow my ability and what I can do but always get anxious before training sessions or sparring, and I think it comes down to this. As soon as I’m in the ring I’m relaxed but the moments and hours before that I’m always on edge. Any advice or anyone can relate to this?

Because right now I don’t feel afraid of not having it on exactly, I feel like I can’t turn it off and when I get ready to I get the doom feeling. I’m rereading what I just wrote it sounds like I’m just scared of the dark but I’m not always.

title: Can’t sleep for the life of me
content: Hi. I’ve had anxiety for what feels like forever but in recent years it’s been so impossible to sleep especially when I have a big day the next morning. Struggling with it so much as it then just bleeds into the next day and makes everything more heightened (I get so emotional with no sleep) and becomes a frustrating cycle. Any tips or tricks that helped you sleep would be appreciated. For more context my main issue is usually not falling asleep but staying asleep as I will be partially sleeping but aware I’m not getting restful sleep/semi conscious basically the entire night. Alternatively I fall asleep temporarily and then my body somewhat wakes up to the point where I have dreams but long ones that last hours and don’t give me any restful sleep. I haven’t slept in two days because I just started my spring semester of grad school but I can’t live like this. Was really challenging last semester too when I couldn’t sleep at all the night before any of my final exams. I’ve taken meds of various sorts but have not found much that has helped - melatonin just makes me more tired but doesn’t put me to sleep and anxiety meds like Xanax are surprisingly unhelpful and don’t do anything for my sleep. I also exercise regularly and have a standard schedule where I wake up and go to sleep at pretty consistent times everyday which used to be very helpful but doesn’t do much on days when the anxiety is overwhelming. Desperate for a solution and I am so tired pls help x

title: Can anyone describe their experience taking medication for mild anxiety?
content:
I’ve heard a lot of descriptions of people with severe anxiety or depression who struggled to get out of the house, or struggled with suicidal thoughts before taking medication. 

My anxiety is nowhere near that level, but it is still unpleasant. I don’t know if what I have is actually a mental illness or just the human condition. Medication is definitely not a life-or-death issue for me, but I’m wondering if it could improve my quality of life. I am seeing a therapist. I have never been to a psychiatrist. 

I’m interested in hearing perspectives from people in similar positions who tried medication. Can it noticeably improve your life, even if you're not doing that badly? 

I’ve heard a lot of descriptions of people with severe anxiety or depression who struggled to get out of the house, or struggled with suicidal thoughts before taking medication. 

My anxiety is nowhere near that level, but it is still unpleasant. I don’t know if what I have is actually a mental illness or just the human condition. Medication is definitely not a life-or-death issue for me, but I’m wondering if it could improve my quality of life. I am seeing a therapist. I have never been to a psychiatrist. 

I’m interested in hearing perspectives from people in similar positions who tried medication. Can it noticeably improve your life, even if you're not doing that badly?

title: I spent five hours on like picking at my skin and scalp and all but it’s just I’m worried I’m faking it all
content:
Hi I’m worried so I am diagnosed with ocd and i have anxiety issues but I spent so long on picking at my body, scratching and scratching the dry skin on my hands, filing dead skin off my feet, plucking hair from my legs with tweezers, scratching at the dandruff in my hair to try to get it all out and combing it over and over, popping pimples, cleaning under my nails, trimming my nails on my toes and fingers, ripping off and pushing back the cuticles just anything and everything. 

But this hasn’t always been an issue for me and I feel anxious cause I’m worried what if I’m faking it because I think I have ocd and what if I’m just trying to prove it or seem like I have it but I’m actually fine and I’m worried about this cause I told my sister about the scratching at my skin. I’m really worried I’m making it all up. I only rarely had these behaviors before and I’m medicated now and have usually been doing ok but this it the worst I’ve done with body habits. 

My scalp hurts, my teeth hurt from flossing till they bleed, my hands have a few open wounds from the scratching, and plucking with tweezers made my legs break out a bit. It’s a lot idk what to do to stop this.

title: How to focus on something else when you are ruminating?
