title: Panic attack from Pristiq
content:
So I have been taking 100MG of Pristiq for about 2 years now due to anxiety, and I recently was prescribed adderal a few months  ago. On Saturday, I took my adderal around 11/12ish and then a few hours later (when I remembered) I took my pristiq. I took my Pristiq around 3/3:30PM, but I usually take it around 9AM every day for work. 

About 30 mins later- I started feeling the worst anxiety and paranoia I’ve ever felt that went on for hours. Before going on pristiq- I struggled with bad anxiety but never anxiety or panic attacks. Since I’ve never really experienced a panic attack- my mind immediately convinced myself that I was “overdosing” on my adderal that I take pretty consistently. My face was numb, non stop shaking, heart racing, chest pain, and sharp anxiety pains that would come and go (which I believe now were “brain zaps”). 

This went on for HOURS and around 10:30 PM after trying everything from cold and hot showers, breathing exercises, walking around and sitting, trying to distract myself, eating, taking hydroxyzine and melatonin; I eventually decided to call myself an uber to the ER because my delusional mind had convinced I was overdosing and having a heart attack. 

After the nurse confirmed my vitals were all OK (other than blood pressure & heart rate obviously) & my EKG came back normal- it was almost instantly that I began to calm down. Just mentally knowing my EKG was normal and that I wasn’t going to have a heart attack or seizure, I guess is all I needed to calm down. 

Can taking Pristiq only a few hours later than normal cause all of this? I’ve never struggled with panic attacks, and I was under the assumption that you have to fully miss a dose for the withdrawal symptoms of Pristiq to occur. Maybe I’m wrong. I know Pristiq can cause brain zaps, which I’ve never felt before- but I believe the “zaps” are what really convinced me I was dying since it is such a unique sensation that I’ve never experienced. It felt like my entire body would twitch and a wave of sharp panic would rush through my body for only a second. So extremely terrifying. 

I still have some lingering anxiety even a few days later and after I’ve returned to taking my pristiq at my normal time. 

Just wondering if this has happened to anyone else? I’m honestly embarrassed about the entire encounter and honestly confused as to why this happened to me.

title: Stomach noises/anxiety/diarrhoea
content:
Hi, so this is my first post on here after finding a few others that I could relate to in some ways, but not fully. This is really to see if anyone else deals with what I do in terms of an anxiety response - this has been an issue for me the past 4 years. It's a niche issue which no one else fully understands, and that leaves me feeling quite isolated - there's comfort in community, so I guess I just wanted to reach out and see if anyone can relate or has experienced something similar.

Although this has been a major issue for me for the last 4 years, it actually started around 11 years ago. I was about 18/19 and I can't remember the exact moment, but my stomach made an awkward noise at one point, and I became really self conscious about it. When I say noise I don't mean like a stomach rumble, I mean like a stomach fart, it's the only way I can describe it, and I kinda feel it happening in my rectum rather than main stomach area, but I'm not releasing gas. It actually took me a long time to realise that the noise would happen specifically because I would hold in gas (if I was in a situation I could not release it in), and after several attempts to release, it moves back up to my stomach and triggers the noise which kinda sounds like a fart anyway - I saw someone on a separate thread describe it as 'all the embarrassment, none of the relief' which is spot on 😂

I then would worry about it happening in certain situations, like hanging out with friends, or in a lecture; I had to leave the room one time because I was so worried it would happen. However, this was at a pretty low level, and as soon as I was out of the situation, I wouldn't think about it. This went on for several years (about 8) - I would worry about it and I would get really nervous in certain situations, but then as soon as I was out of the situation, I wouldn't think about it until the next time.

When I was 26/27 I started a new job in an office, it was a completely different environment to anywhere I'd worked before (my previous job we had the radio on, I had 3 breaks a day, it was quite chatty and casual and you could work on different reception desks). In the new office, save for phone calls, it was so silent you could hear a pin drop and there was only a small group of us working in the office. This was my worst nightmare because of my issue and I just went into complete meltdown mode. Every day I had to go into the office, I would wake up feeling sick, start wretching so violently I would almost throw up, would wretch all the way to work on the tube, the street, and when I got to work I would have diarrhoea all day, I couldn't eat, I ended up losing about half a stone there over a couple of months. It was hell. My body was trying to tell me to get the hell out of there. I ended up deciding to leave because I couldn't cope anymore, but amazingly giving my mind that release, my symptoms actually stopped, and I was able to stay there. However, I didn't deal with the root of the problem, and a few months later this started showing up in the other areas of my life. I started having anxiety attacks in certain situations which basically just consisted of me getting awful diarrhoea and feeling really nauseous. These situations consisted of the theatre, comedy club, hairdressers, eyelash appointments - and worst of all, I would get it every time I got called into the managers office for a chat (which was very regularly). I realised the trigger is anywhere I can't easily leave (or it would be awkward/embarrassing to leave) and for it to be quiet enough to hear a stomach noise. It was hell and I'm still struggling with it 4 years later.

I ended up doing hypnotherapy which was amazing - it managed to stop these reactions and I felt incredible for the first time in a long time. I still had the fear about the stomach noises though, but I'm not sure I'll ever be rid of that. However, around 7/8 months after doing hypnotherapy, I got triggered by a life event and all my symptoms came back ten fold. I had a new job at that point which I loved, but it got so bad to the point I was going to the toilet over 10 times in a couple of hours because my stomach issues just wouldn't stop and just being in the office became a trigger again. I had to have time off work. My hypnotherapist wasn't really helpful the second time round - he helped a bit, but he didn't have a lot of answers and it wasn't quite working in the same way as before. He ended up saying that we 'failed' and he couldn't do anymore to help me - we had to stop having sessions. I've since done CBT, EMDR, and none of it's worked. I'm now seeing another hypnotherapist, but I hate to say I feel a little skeptical.

As of now, I'm struggling with diarrhoea every time I have a work meeting, and in other areas like beauty appointments and the theatre which I love going to 😢 it's basically become a conditioned fear response in my body and because of past experiences, my mind recognises certain situations as (incorrectly) dangerous, and is triggering my flight response to get out of there to safety. It's really evolved from the fear of stomach noises and now it's so difficult to live my life when I get scared and uncomfortable in so many normal every day situations. However, the fear of stomach noises is still there even if I don't get the diarrhoea, as that was the original fear which I think to some extent I can never be fully rid of. Being in a work meeting or an appointment with your eyes taped shut and having to hold in explosive diarrhoea is awful!! I've also struggled on dates, when I sleep next to someone new I can't sleep the entire night because my body won't let me and I'm worried I might make a noise. I've had anxiety attacks when staying over at someone's before and I've had to leave a date early because I got surprised with a comedy club on the date and got super uncomfortable and had to get out of there 🙃

Has anyone had anything similar? I would be grateful to know if any therapy I haven't tried has been helpful for this kind of issue, as I really don't know what to do anymore. Sorry for the super long post - not sure anyone will be arsed to read this, But it was pretty cathartic to write 😂

title: Fear of throwing up on trains
content:
I (21M) had a panic attack a year ago on the T (subway) and ever since I’ve had a fear of throwing up on the trains. 

I’ve been diagnosed with anxiety long before that, what sparked my diagnosis was my body having a conditioned response to nausea - in other words, anything feels off with my body, anything goes wrong, I immediately assume I’m going to throw up and that’s what started my panic attack. 

Does anyone have advice for how to deal with this? I get really anxious on the train, sometimes to the point where I have to get off at the next stop, because I’m scared of throwing up and there not being a “safe” space to throw up where no one can see me.

title: Generalized Anxiety and 4th Day on Lexapro
content:
TW: health anxiety and hypochondria, panic attacks

I am in my 30s, and overall have been pretty anxiety free. When I was a kid, I would always be afraid of people dying, me dying, people leaving and not coming back, etc. This fear has come and went throughout most my life, resulting in pretty significant distress and maybe a mini panic attack every couple years. I do remember several times around the age of 10-14 where I would go outside because I felt like I couldn't breathe and would check to see if my fingernails were turning blue. Now that I am typing this out, I suppose I have never been anxiety free lol. Wow.

Anyway, at 28 I had a full blown panic attack when I found out I had fatty liver disease. This heightened state of anxiety lasted two days and my face had this crazy tingling sensation on one side that eventually convinced me to go to the ER, thinking I was having a stroke or something. Of course, everything was fine. Ever since that big panic attack I have been dealing with almost daily anxiety. Occasionally I would go weeks or months feeling pretty good. Other times, I would spend days feeling like I was on the brink of a panic attack.

A month ago, I had another panic attack after seeing a patient with mouth cancer. Due to ear and mouth pain I had been having, I was convinced I had mouth cancer. I was puking, crying, having diarrhea. My face began to tingle again, I felt disease, short of breath, and like my throat was closing. I left work to go to a walk in to get it checked out and the issue was that I had fluid behind my ear. Over the next 4 weeks I continued to go in and out of crying and panicking fits thinking there was something wrong. The tingling on my face persisted, and by that time I was convinced I had MS or a brain tumor or aneurysm. I was afraid to go to sleep or walk alone thinking I could collapse at any second.

After my first panic attack I went to a place that taught about meditation and really got into it. It was the only thing that helped in addition to some of the mantras I would repeat to myself. Ever since these have helped me, but they only bring me temporary relief in the moment. I knew I could no longer live like this.

I scheduled an appointment with a psychiatrist and she was really great. I couldn't have been luckier. I was started on lexapro and have been taking it for 4 days. I know most say it can take weeks to feel a difference, but I swear by the 2nd day I have noticed a change. One of the biggest being my mind is not CONSTANTLY active. I don't think of or plan conversations before they happen. I am not thinking of my future 4 decades in advance. I do not think of and fear and cry about me or my wife getting old and dying. My face hasn't tingled or felt like it is having microspasms for the past few days. The pressure in my forehead is gone. I haven't felt sick to my stomach (except today because I drank coffee- anytime my stomach feels bad I feel anxious, and vice versa). My breathing feels clearer, not really sure what that's about & maybe it's a placebo thing...or just the relief I feel in my body? I have had issues with brain fog but I also have sleep apnea and use CPAP but when my nose is really stuffed up I can't use it so I am not sure if that has improved yet or if it is related to anxiety or not so the verdict is still out on that one. Yesterday, I felt my brain fog was "deeper" in my mind, more central, rather than in my forehead if that makes sense, and then it lifted a few hours after I took my lexapro, but it could be that it dissipated once I got enough blood and oxygen flowing up there because I didnt use my cpap the night before lol.

I want to say that I am a very skeptical person and that after some bad experiences with psychedelics I was terrified of medication because I was terrified of having that feeling like I wasn't myself. After only 4 days I will say that I am upset that I didn't do this sooner. My mind feels relatively clear. I am living in the present. I feel more focused. I feel less fidgety. I actually don't think I've been shaking my legs for days now, and I don't feel like I'm going to explode if I'm not shaking them. My jaw isn't clenched. The only thing that I notice is that now that my mind isn't constantly active, I sometimes find myself just kind of staring into the imaginary abyss, not thinking, just sitting..but not worrying, or planning, or catastrophically thinking, or feeling a pain in my body thinking it's some disease. It's not a bad thing, just different. Now that my mind isn't so busy, I think I will finally have the mental capacity to do all the things I'd want to do but never start. I have even felt like leaving the house the past 2 days! I don't worry as much about my wife getting in a wreck or shot or anything like that. I think I may have ADHD as well, but I want to give this a couple months before I do anything else in terms of medication. Anyway, if you have any questions about lexapro or my experience just comment!

title: OCD over my bf losing interest in me
content:
First off, I know I'm probably gonna get lots of hate and criticism for this post, since this is reddit. Also, all of this is probably made worse right now by me PMSing real bad.

I spent years feeling sad and worthless because no matter how I tried, no one wanted me romantically. No one ever asked me out, had a crush on me, or showed any interest in me, except for ONE guy back when we were teens. I tried online dating. It was always "I'm sorry, but this isn't going to work out, we don't have the right chemistry, youre not my type, I'm not physically attracted to you..." etc etc. Either that or they'd block me as soon as they saw pics of me. If I got a crush on someone, thet never liked me back. The one time I was brave enough to shoot my shot, I ended up getting rejected with all the reasons why I wasn't right for him. I know it's probably partly because I'm not attractive at all.

Back in October, I made an online friend. We'll call him L. L and I got along super well, and in November we both admitted we really liked each other and are now in a LDR.

The first month or so was amazing. We were both so happy. He was SO sweet to me, always telling me such sweet and adorable things. He made me feel so loved and wanted all the time. He was also super caring. If I was sad or not feeling well (which happens often bc of my chronic illness) he would tell me how sad it made him, how he wished he were here to look after me and comfort me, tell me what he'd do if he were here to take care of me, etc. 

He would tell me the sweetest things all the time like "Sometimes I wonder if you're just a dream I will wake up from because I just can't believe you are real, you're so perfect, I'm obsessed with you, I wish I could make you see how absolutely beautiful I find you, if my coworkers ask me why I'm so happy I will just tell them I'm talking to this amazing girl..." 

Fast forward in January, I still get a little bit of affection, but nothing like the way he was in the first month. He doesn't say things like that anymore. I can tell he doesn't feel as strongly for me anymore. He is not really caring anymore. If I'm sad or ill it's just "Goodnight, hope you feel better." No affection or care or empathy. 

I'm convinced he is losing interest in me. The only thing is, I'm not sure if he really is, or if I'm just being overly anxious/OCD/overthinking. From the beginning, I did have a slight fear that he would stop liking me or lose interest in me and now this fear has just gone out of control and taken over everything. This has made me clingy, made me constantly try too hard to make him like me, made me overanalyze everything he says and does. I don't even enjoy the time I spend with him anymore. I'm too stressed and sad. I almost want to break up with him or ghost him because I can't handle this anymore. I want to save my heart before it gets broken.

Way back in the beginning, I told him I was just waiting for the day he tells me he doesn't want me anymore. He responded lovingly and emphatically "You will be waiting forever!". Nowadays, occasionally I bring up or hint at the fear that he will lose interest in me. He gives me very matter of fact, affectionless replies like "Well if I do, that's on me, it's not a you problem" and "We can still be friends if that happens". I couldn't stand to just be friends with him. I've fallen for him too hard 

I cry a lot and feel sad because I think he's losing interest in me and I feel worthless, unloved, unwanted, not good enough. I should have known that someone actually wanting me was impossible. 

Another thing that has been tearing me apart is that he's made it clear that he doesn't love me, he only likes me. He wants to wait until he means it to tell me he loves me. But at this point, I don't think he will ever love me. This breaks my heart into pieces, because I love him. I cry about it so much. It tears me apart.

The last issue here is that earlier this month, he got REALLY mad and we had an argument and actually didn't talk for a day because he found out that a year ago I got taken advantage of. He acted like I had purposely cheated on him and then lied to him about it (didn't tell him till this month). I thought he was going to end it to me. He said he has to sympathy for what happened to me because all I had to do was say no or stop talking to the guy once I knew things weren't right. 

Yesterday was the straw that broke the camel's back. I read a post by a girl who had also been taken advantage of and was afraid to tell her long distance bf. She finally told him, and his response was SO perfect and so genuinely loving and caring. I could tell he loves and cares for her so much. This is so selfish, but reading about his reaction broke my heart with jealousy and sadness. If my bf really cared and wanted me, that's the way he would have reacted.

 I had already been super anxious and sad thinking about my bf losing interest in me. This post broke me and I cried for 5 hours. I still feel messed up this morning. My bf knew I went to bed crying and very sad last night (I blamed PMS). But all he said was "Whats making you so sad?" and "Hope you feel better." In the beginning, if I cried, he would tell me how he wished he was here for me, tell me how sad it made him that I was sad, and tell me he wished he could cuddle me until I felt better 

I'm just so sad, and the anxiety this relationship is causing me is too much to handle. I was happier when we were just friends. I know that nobody wants me. Nobody loves me romantically and they never will. I'm not good enough, not pretty enough, not special enough, not worthy of love. Please give me advice.

title: Hands and feet more clammy since starting running
content:
Sort of a DAE, but it’s weird. 
36, male, no diagnosed ailments other than health anxiety at times. 

I’ve never been a clammy person unless I was super stressed out. Even then, it’s short lived. 
I’ve been going for a mile or two every day for a couple weeks, building up endurance. 
As of last Tuesday, I suddenly have clammy hands and feet. Mostly feet. 
They’re not soaked, but there is tangible moisture on the bottom of my feet even when just sitting around. 
Doesn’t happen when I sleep but starts as I’m laying in bed snoozing my alarm. 
The REAL weird part is that it’s not worse after a run. It’s almost lessened by running, until I get home and relax. 

No other symptoms. Doctor isn’t concerned. 
The only change to my life recently is it’s cold as shit outside in Milwaukee and I’ve been jogging and running more often then ever before. But it’s weird that they’d be so icky when I’m not running. 

Idk man. Anyone got insight?

title: My Anxiety and Nausea is ruining my life
content:
Hello, F(21) English isn’t my first language so beware of the fact I will do a lot of typos lol.

I have always had a weak stomach since childhood even as a little kid (I’d always throw up apparently according to my mom) but I don’t remember having a bad stomach around primary and middle school. 
In the last years of high school i started developing nausea?? And have seen doctors for it but after some check ups they always said it was psychological so I didn’t really cared much and went on with my life. 

In university tho, my stress has gotten very high so is my ocd etc. So I finally decided to see a psychiatrist and they diagnosed me with anxiety disorder (and a slight case of ocd) 

But my problem is that my anxiety makes me so nauseous that I carry a dozens of stomach pills with me and a bag in case I’d need to throw up and everytime I feel like I’m gonna throw up I get a panick attack which makes my stomach even worse (it’s like a cycle) I almost threw away a very big opportunity because of it. 

Some days I’m less nauseous than others but somehow I’m always very nauseous and it makes me anxious that I always rethink before making any plans or travel. And I study in another city than my hometown so it also makes it so hard for me to attend school (attendance is mandatory) I remember going to my finals with a bag to throw up etc. (I’m a last year student in uni tho)

I was wondering if any of you had similar symptoms to mine, and how did you guys coped up with it? Cuz rn I quit my anxiety pills since they also make my stomach act up. Do you guys have any advice ?

(I also can’t eat certain foods because I’m so scared that they’ll hurt my stomach so I avoid eating and eat the bare minimum which makes me lose a significant amount of weight when my stomach is at its worse, then I gain again then it happens again etc.)

title: Weekly Pain - Can be caused by Hydroxie
content:
I’m sorry but I wasn’t sure where else to ask. I have recently gotten sober off methadone two years ago. I have PTSD, anxiety, depression, etc. due to really bad childhood but that aside, I was recommended by my counselor to try weed. Well I’ve been using the kind from gas station that has CBD & 3% THC & it does sometimes seem to help. I now have my medical marijuana card but idk it doesn’t seem to effect me & been told it’s because something to do with taking Methadone all those years messed up some kind of receptors in my brain but I digress because that’s not what I’m here about, just giving lil back story.
I read that Hyrdroxie can help with Anxiety so I gave it a try. N yes it really helps. But here’s issue, a couple times a week I wake up hurting, like there’s ice in my veins, & the pain will continue until I take a Hydroxie. 
I don’t know if it’s the Hydroxie causing it, the gas station gummies or something different all together.
I didn’t know if anyone here has had any experience with these things or those feelings because I’m on the edge n can barely take it anymore.
I have so many other issues & this one has me standing on my toes on the edge trying not to jump. So please if anyone has any advice. And I know I’m filling h an addiction with another with Cannabis & Hydroxie, I have that guilt so please don’t beat me up on that part. Believe me I do it enough myself. I’m just trying to find a way to survive, I honestly don’t know how people get out of bed wanting to do so & enjoy life. I envy & crave that so much. Okay, sorry off subject.
Right now I’m just trying to figure out the physical pain I feel. It’s like if you get really cold & your body hurts on the inside.
So if anyone has any advice or has experienced something like this please please let me know, thank you

title: I’m letting my anxiety ruin my relationship and I don’t know what to do
content:
Hi everyone. So I (26F) started dating my boyfriend (26M) about 2 and a half months ago. We just made things official last week. So far this relationship has been very healthy, he’s a very good partner and I really have fallen in love with him. He’s very loving and shows it to me everyday. However, I struggle with anxiety and I feel like I will end up sabotaging everything due to it. 

We’ve had some arguments (just small ones that aren’t really a big deal) and every single time my brain convinces me that I messed up everything and that he’ll break up with me. He has already told me that he’ll never leave me because of an argument, that he’ll always want to solve our problems together. However I’m extremely apologetic to the point where I know it annoys him, and I’m constantly blaming myself for everything and I just can’t forgive myself when I make a small mistake. 

My anxiety is also affecting our sex life, I never initiate sex because of it, it makes me extremely anxious to be “bad” in bed even though he always tells me how much he likes it. I’ve also been depressed and with very high stress due to personal reasons and it’s basically lowered my libido to the point I never even think about sex, and it’s just so weird because I used to be very active with my exes. I’ve found it hard to explain my anxiety to him, he feels like there’s something wrong with him and i feel super guilty because it’s not his fault at all. 

I just feel like I’ll end up self sabotaging and ruining everything. I don’t want to lose him because I really love him and I want this to work. I guess I’m just looking for advice from people who have been in similar situations. I’m on antidepressants and anxiety meds but sadly can’t afford therapy right now and I feel lost, the meds help but I have no therapist to talk to.

title: Why is my anxiety more mental than physical now?
content: Three weeks ago I had an anxiety relapse, and I was having panic attacks (trembling, pounding heart, upset stomach etc). Now it's transitioned to just mental/emotional symptoms (racing thoughts, persistent feelings of dread, unreality, etc) it's like a dark cloud that's hanging over me, and I don't know what to do. The physical symptoms used to calm down after a few hours, but these symptoms feel relentless. I've tried the Dare method, but I'm terrified these symptoms will not end, and I will never enjoy life again, so I have a difficult time really accepting them. :( is such a transition common? Is there hope for me?

title: Struggling with anxiety in leadership roles - looking for work options that don’t involve managing people
content:
**TLDR:**  
I (40F) have GAD, social anxiety, and a high-masking introverted personality. Despite managing my mental health through meds, therapy, and exercise, my anxiety attacks are triggered by work. I excel at solving problems but keep getting pushed into leadership roles, which I don’t enjoy and trigger more anxiety. Has anyone found a job where they can work alone and earn well without the leadership stress?

\------------------------------------

Hey there! I (40F) have a GAD diagnosis, social anxiety, and a high-masking introvert personality. After several years, I’ve managed to get it all under control through medication, therapy, and exercise. Most aspects of my life are going well, and I’m proud of how far I’ve come. However, every single anxiety attack I experience stems from work.

I love working alone and enjoy solving strategic problems. I’ve worked hard to become a specialist in several areas. But I always end up in leadership roles because, as an overthinker, I tend to come up with unique solutions. People see this as a superpower, so when they notice my ability to find solutions others don’t, they often promote me to lead teams and train others to do what I do.

Here’s the problem: I don’t like people, I don’t enjoy training them, and I never wanted to be a people leader. I’ve tried approaching it methodologically, but I just can’t seem to make it work. Additionally, a higher role means more exposure, which leads to stuttering and a foggy brain in front of extroverted colleagues who don’t seem to understand what anxiety feels like.

I’ve changed jobs several times, but I always find myself at the same point: starting strong, getting a team, and eventually entering the “I hate everyone and everything” phase. This increases my anxiety attacks and leaves me counting down the days until retirement.

My last anxiety attack was especially brutal, and I ended up hurting myself. Has anyone else experienced this? Did you manage to find a job where you work alone and earn decent pay? I’d really appreciate any input. Thanks so much for reading this rant!

title: DAE have sleeping issues in certain places?

hi all.

i, 24f, have had diagnosed GAD since i was ~8 years old. through the years ive been in therapy, tried different medications, different routines, etc. one thing has always stayed the same: i sleep like shit. 

i’ve recently had a lot of issues with insomnia once again. except…. it’s only when i sleep at my apartment… i think? i often times find myself awake shortly after ive fallen asleep — usually about 1.5 hours after. either i can’t fall asleep or i get woken up by who knows what. i only sleep when matter exhaustion hits me. i’ve considered sleep apnea but…. i don’t know. i’ve woken up gasping for air but also when im awake at night i notice i have an issue swallowing. i don’t know if this is an anxiety issue or a real health concern.

has anyone experienced anything like this?

title: experiencing something that fuels anxiety even further
content:
My anxiety makes me extremely suspicious of almost all strangers around me whenever I’m outside (excluding some which I deem ‘safe’ in my head for whatever reason whether it be that they have children or etc). I cannot go out without looking over my shoulder, accessing the person who’s about to pass me, flinching at any slight noise of panic/anger, just generally feeling like something bad is about to happen at any moment. 

I try to calm myself down but there have been a few incidents throughout my life where my fears have been proven right and that I’ve had to face things that I fear having to face whenever I go outside. Today, I was in a city and a man entered a shop I was in and started trying to capture everyone’s attention. We all laughed it off. The store had only female employees and female customers. He proceeded to ask every woman to fistbump or shake his hand. His hand was extremely dirty but the women did it anyway. It was clear that they were not pleased with this and were feeling nervous. I felt really uncomfortable by this and didn’t want to feel pressured in having to touch a stranger, so I just laughed it off but didn’t touch him at all. He proceeded to follow me, making suggestive comments and getting extremely up close and personal. In that moment I felt in danger and like it could escalate to something horrible happening. I had a panic attack in the store. 

Eventually one of the employees managed to make him leave, and later on when I spotted him a few streets away, he was getting arrested. 

Incidents like these only further fuel my fears of the dangers that lie outside. How am supposed to reassure myself like my counsellor said before by saying that all my fears are just in my head, when things like this happen?

title: Scared to post anywhere
content: Idk if it’s anxiety or what but whenever I try to post anything anywhere I get this surge of doubt and fear, does anyone know how to remedy this?/is this normal?

title: I only lasted 3 days and now, regretfully, I'm flying home.
content:
I came to Japan on my own 3 days ago expecting to stay for 4-6 weeks. The last time I travelled alone on a backpacking trip was in 2018, but I spent the first 3 months with a friend, which really helped me feel safe and able to adjust to this new way of living. Afterwards, I travelled solo in Taiwan and the Philippines. 

I flew from the UK. I was so, SO excited. I made a rough itinerary for the first 2 weeks, had a loose plan for the remainder. Was going to hire a campervan and explore the countryside, too. 

As soon as I landed and started walking through the steets of Shinjuku to my hostel, I started to feel teary. I was alone. Why am I feeling like this, I thought? You've done this before. I thought I might have a good cry once I arrived there, but it didn't happen. I went to sleep. The next day after a pretty rough night, I woke up excited to explore. By the nighttime, I was pretty exhausted. Might have done too much as I walked 30000 steps. 

I didn't sleep well again. Had a lot of fear around the lack of sleep. I think the brutal jet lag (which I never expected and hadn't experienced like this before) and sleep deprivation caused me to feel overly emotional, overwhelmed and always fearing the worst. I am an anxious person generally, but I don't think I have the self-confidence or belief that I can depend on myself alone. Not rely on others for comfort or help. I tried to have a calmer day. I felt quite anxious the entire time. Had no appetite. I really struggled to deal with the stress of finding food that I wanted. I gave up and went back to the hostel.

I'm now sat at the airport waiting to fly home, after calling numerous people and feeling like I couldn't handle being there any longer. Haven't stopped crying the entire time. Feeling quite distraught and disappointed with myself. I was definitely catastrophising everything. I know that if someone was with me, I would have been okay. And most probably, if I'd lasted one or two more days, I'd get over the jet lag and enjoy the rest of my holiday. I was just so overwhelmed and missing the people I care about and fearing that I can't depend on myself in case something goes wrong. 

I know Japan will still be there, but I was craving this for so long and needed a break after a stressful work period. Now, I'm just going back to normal life again. I feel like a massive failure 😔

title: The anxiety I'm feeling isn't just in my head
content:
You know, I think one of the toughest things about having anxiety and trying to get others to understand it is this: if we, as people with anxiety challenges, could just turn it off, we would. And sure, I know there’s a part of being anxious that people might say is “all in your head,” but I think it’s so much more than that. It’s not just in the head—it’s trauma that’s literally trapped in the body. There are experiences in life that caused this.

I can remember moments where I wasn’t as anxious, and I’m working really hard to get back to those moments. But yeah, it’s hard, because sometimes mental health challenges aren’t visible from the outside. It’s easy for others to discredit them or to assume it should be simple to just “stop” the symptoms.

When I think about it, though, the parasympathetic nervous system (you know, the system responsible for calming the body) is often in overdrive for years in many cases of anxiety. Switching from that constant state of fight-or-freeze mode to a balanced and calm state isn’t something the body even recognizes as normal. It takes practice, deliberate effort, and a lot of unlearning and undoing negative behavioral patterns before you can start to see certain effects ease up.

title: mirtazapine for physical symptoms
content:
Hi! I’ve been experiencing general anxiety for more than half a year now. Since I study psychology, I knew I needed to start therapy right away and did so (a mix of somatic and trauma-informed methods) and it has worked wonders on the way I process experiences mentally, and I feel really balanced in mind, however, somatic sympthoms like nausea or troubles with sleeping persist and often makes me feel disconnected from my body. So I decided to consult a psychiatrist, who put me on autogenic training and 15mg of Mirtazapine (her reasoning was that the nausea [and thus disordered eating and weight loss, I was underweight to begin with] and disorganised sleep pattern doesn’t allow my vegetative nervous system to regulate itself and regenerate) 

My reasoning to seek out a psychiatrist wasn’t to get medication but for a doctor to see if I have any indications of an underlying medical condition that could perhaps perpetuate my physical symptoms (everything seems to be fine except my vitamin D levels, though I do have my own doubts about my endocrine system for other reasons) but medication is what I’ve got! I’ve been a bit iffy about going on them in general but she’s got a great point about how it could help the eating and sleep disorders, which in turn could alleviate my physical symptoms, so I’ll consult my therapist too and might give it a try.

What I’ve wanted to ask is did anyone with similar troubles try this medication, and if so, how was it?

title: I can't handle this & I'm genuinely terrified
content:
I simply don't know what to do so I guess I'll start at the beginning. I'm 46 and have been experiencing sharp chest pains and crippling attacks that feel like I'm having a heart attack. Very sporadic poking in my heart area, tingling up the back of my neck, left arm is fluctuating and pulsating, can't breathe. A trip to the ER and 2 EKGs + blood work show I'm not having a heart attack. 1st EKG Dr said benign repolarization which is basically athletes heart and occurs in 25% of elite athletes. I saw a cardiologist in 2022 for palpitations and aside from a slightly enlarged heart she also found athletes heart. This is different than before, my heart is constantly bounding meaning I can feel it all the time especially when I try to sleep so I'm not sleeping at all maybe 3 hours a night. People in my life think it's panic attacks so my gf is an NP and ordered me Xanax Friday night. Normally Xanax knocks me in my fanny. Heart started Fri night, after 15 minutes Xanax made it stop. Saturday morning another hardcore attack happened but trying to deal with it naturally I put a meditation video on and rocked back and forth. When I came to I was covered in snot and tears with an overwhelming sense of loneliness and abandonment. Another attack last night took half a Xanax .25 mgs but after 20 minutes it didn't help so took another. After 25 minutes they went away but the usual very loopy and groggy feeling I'VE ALWAYS HAD wasn't there. I've never taken that much and I felt normal. We took our dogs out and when I came home hour or so later body was heavy but I was still shocked at how normal I felt. Prior to all this happening I felt like Deniro in Analyze this. Thought panic attacks that felt like heart attacks were impossible, it just didn't compute for me. I also never understood how people took Xanax and felt normal. 

This started 10 days ago and has gotten significantly worse since last Thursday. Growing up in Hell's Kitchen, my close circle of friends in highschool are either dead or in jail. Mid 90s were just different I guess and can't control who you vibe with. I went to the Marines in 2000 and had 2 deployments to Iraq and 1 to Afghanistan. Anyone I was close with was killed or they now live on the other side of the country. I hit the girlfriend lottery, I'm amazed at how lucky I am. She's the most supportive and genuinely good human I've ever been around. I don't need much, her our dogs and my plants I'm the richest lad in the world. Not close with my family since my Mom passed and tbh wasn't very close before that either. When I came home from the Marines I'm a people person but couldn't be around anyone. Id feel uncomfortable on trains after a few stops, couldn't sleep but nothing like this. If there's a sudden loud noise like thunder, fireworks etc the WiFi in my brain shuts off and I'm basically catatonic for a few minutes. Awake and aware but trapped inside my body. It's something I've had to disclose on every first date because that's something a potential partner should know before getting involved. Doesn't happen often but it does happen. If I prepare myself and expect it im fine but who can predict gnarly thunder lol. 

Since I came home I've unintentionally pushed people away. I can talk to someone at Lowe's for an hour but any relationships I don't pursue or put effort in if that makes sense. Growing up I switched schools K-9 9x (not exaggerating) so I've always had gift of gab but anyone I get close to gets taken from me so that + the trauma from the Marines developing close relationships has been difficult. I'm seeing a cardiologist the 31st, earliest I can get in but these attacks keep happening. I'm 6'5" 260 lbs and have been in elite shape my entire life. The last 7 months I've had two major surgeries. Torn meniscus in June and rebuilt my inner and middle ear end of November so I've taken a lot of time off from gym and my body is very very tight. I had just started lifting heavy again when these pains started except I know what those feel like. I do cupping at home, electric stim, massage gun, have a candy cane looking massage thing that is able to get huge knots out but hurts like hell. Haven't seen my acupuncturist in a bit and she thinks I have thoracic other syndrome but the other stuff is anxiety. I was convinced Friday I was having cardiac arrest. The fact that Xanax works within a few minutes and I've felt normal afterwards, maybe I've suppressed things I've tried really hard to forget and it's bursting through my subconscious. 

Saw the head navy shrink upon discharging and told him what I've shared. Couldn't sleep, uncomfortable around people, anytime I see a helicopter (long story), the loud noises etc. He writes me a script but it's 120 Oxy 80s. I said "sir I don't have cancer I just want to feel normal again." He replied and I quote, "you grunts never cease to amaze me. You all walk in here and think you know everything. You want to contribute to the growing epidemic of serviceman that have taken their own life go right ahead but please sign here showing you're refusing treatment please." Never forgot that moment. I can still smell the room like it was yesterday. I was stunned and initial reaction was GFYS so I never went back and tried on my own. Nature, the beach, gym and music all seemed to help and I'm a lot luckier than most. Turns out they did this to every one in my unit and I'm assuming others. 

I know I need therapy and need to commit to it like I have squats. These attacks are crippling and my EKG and blood show I'm not having heart attacks but they feel so real and they're the scariest thing I've ever experienced. If you've made it this far, thank you. I genuinely don't know what to do because there are people saying crap like "you get the vaccine?" which I did but telling me that isn't helping calm me down. I've never felt this scared and hoping this ends yesterday. Feels like something sharp poking my heart, very sporadic and I only feel these pains abd weird feelings on my left side. When I went to hospital it felt like 250 pounds standing on my chest.

title: Has anyone dealt with random adrenaline surges and somatic panic attacks with no clear trigger?
content:
Background and Development of Symptoms

From age 12, I became acutely aware of how others perceived me, which marked the onset of severe anxiety accompanied by somatic symptoms, most notably excessive sweating. Between the ages of 12 and 15, I began experimenting with a variety of substances (curious of exploring the bounds of my conscious experience) including psilocybin, LSD, benzodiazepines, cocaine, and MDMA, while eventually being prescribed medications like SSRIs for anxiety. Zoloft provided moderate relief, but other medications, such as buspirone, exacerbated my condition significantly.

By 19, I was experiencing severe depression with frequent suicidal ideation (for 6 years), alongside pervasive anxiety. Much of my anxiety manifested as anticipatory fears tied to specific events, social interactions, or intrusive thoughts, and somatic symptoms such as sweating and gastrointestinal distress were a constant presence. Chronic insomnia compounded my issues, leading to a six-year reliance on diphenhydramine (Benadryl) for sleep—a practice I now understand to have detrimental long-term effects.

At age 19, I was diagnosed with bipolar depression and prescribed Seroquel, which proved moderately effective in improving sleep (via histamine receptor antagonism) and reducing anxiety, especially in conjunction with gabapentin. However, at age 23, I developed a new form of anxiety that differed from my previous experiences. This anxiety was marked by sudden, random surges of panic unconnected to any identifiable trigger. These episodes involved a rush of adrenaline, accompanied by somatic symptoms such as tingling skin, difficulty breathing, and an overwhelming sense of discomfort in existing—a stark contrast to my prior anticipatory anxiety. While my anticipatory anxiety also expanded to fears—driving, choking, flying, traveling, etc.

Post-Seroquel Period and the Emergence of Cognitive Symptoms

At age 24, I self-titrated off Seroquel and began focusing on supplementation to support my mental and physical health. My regimen included EPA/DHA omega-3s, vitamin D3, magnesium glycinate, and later glycine for sleep. Over the following year, I felt better than ever—my anxiety was significantly reduced, my mood stabilized, and my overall quality of life improved.

However, in October 2024 (age 26), I increased my glycine intake from 1 g to 2 g due to heightened stress. Soon after, I began experiencing word retrieval issues and memory difficulties, which I attributed to the higher glycine dose. I discontinued glycine entirely, but this reintroduced the random somatic panic attacks and physical discomfort I had previously experienced.

Current Symptoms and Hypothesis

Currently, I experience:
	•	Random somatic panic attacks, characterized by sudden adrenaline surges, tingling sensations, and an overwhelming sense of discomfort.
	•	Cognitive discomfort, including difficulties with focus, memory, and word retrieval.
	•	Heightened sensitivity to psychoactive substances (e.g., caffeine, sugar, Tylenol), with noticeable shifts in my consciousness after consumption.
	•	Increased sensitivity to sensory stimuli, such as sounds and sights.

My hypothesis is as follows:
	1.	Glutamate/GABA Dysregulation:
Years of stress, medication use, and glycine supplementation disrupted the balance between glutamate (excitatory) and GABA (inhibitory) neurotransmitters. This imbalance has left glutamate overactive and GABA underactive, leading to overstimulation of NMDA receptors. The result is heightened sensitivity, random adrenaline spikes, and somatic anxiety.
	2.	NMDA Receptor Overactivation:
Excessive glutamate has caused NMDA receptor overactivation, which fuels my panic attacks and cognitive discomfort. This dysfunction also likely underpins my hypersensitivity to external stimuli and substances.
	3.	HPA Axis Dysregulation:
Chronic stress, insomnia, and medication withdrawal have left my HPA axis (stress regulation system) overactive. My body struggles to regulate cortisol and adrenaline, causing random surges of stress hormones that manifest as panic episodes.
	
Current Plan and Rationale

I have adopted a supplement regimen to address these root causes:
	1.	NAC (N-Acetylcysteine):
	•	Purpose: Reduces glutamate overactivity, calms NMDA receptor hyperactivity, and boosts glutathione production to mitigate oxidative stress and repair neuronal damage.
	•	Goal: Stabilize the nervous system and reduce random panic attacks.
	2.	Taurine:
	•	Purpose: Enhances natural GABA activity, inhibits NMDA receptor overactivation, and stabilizes calcium signaling in neurons.
	•	Goal: Support neurotransmitter balance, reduce somatic anxiety, and improve sleep.
	3.	Omega-3 EPA/DHA:
	•	Purpose: Reduces neuroinflammation and supports overall brain function and emotional resilience.
	•	Goal: Provide a foundation for long-term nervous system repair.
	4.	Magnesium Threonate:
	•	Purpose: Supports GABA function and modulates NMDA receptor activity, helping to calm the nervous system.
	•	Goal: Enhance relaxation and improve cognitive function.
	5.	Vitamin D3/K2:
	•	Purpose: Regulates neurotransmitter activity and supports overall brain health.
	•	Goal: Maintain optimal health and resilience.
	6.	Astaxanthin:
	•	Purpose: Reduces oxidative stress and protects neurons from further damage.
	•	Goal: Enhance antioxidant support alongside NAC.

Conclusion

I believe the combination of stress, medications, and glycine dysregulation left my nervous system hypersensitive, with glutamate overactivity, NMDA receptor dysfunction, and HPA axis dysregulation at the core of my symptoms. This has resulted in a state of heightened anxiety and sensitivity, which no previous interventions (e.g., benzodiazepines, SSRIs, or even CBT) have fully addressed.

My current approach—focused on NAC, taurine, and other supportive supplements—is designed to treat the root causes rather than mask symptoms. While these issues have been debilitating, I remain optimistic that this targeted approach will help restore balance to my nervous system over time.

At the age of 20, I made the decision to stop all recreational substance use. I never experienced dependency, but I realized I wanted to fight for my life and work toward stability. Since then, I’ve achieved significant progress in managing my depression, finding a level of stability I hadn’t experienced before.

I’ve also taken deliberate steps to optimize my overall well-being, including adopting a whole-food diet and eliminating carcinogens and endocrine disruptors from my environment. This includes using only clean skincare, makeup, and cleaning supplies. However, despite these efforts, I continue to struggle with anxiety—specifically, random bursts of adrenaline that seem to come out of nowhere.

These episodes are not tied to specific thoughts or events. They involve a sudden, overwhelming surge of physical discomfort: my body feels wiry, tingly, and restless, and my mind feels blank but trapped in a state of pure panic. It’s as though my entire system rebels against existing for no apparent reason.

Has anyone experienced anything similar, and if so, how did you address it?

title: Wishing I could release anxiety through calmer means
content:
The most effective way for me to calm down through a healthy and calm means is through exercise, which mostly helps me get to a point where I can cry while doing so and then I feel great. But this is kind of hard to do at 2am when people are sleeping and it's dark and cold and not smart for a woman to be walking around at.

But all the other coping mechanisms just don't quite do the job. The stretching, the meditating, the breathing, the walking up and down the stairs, counting my blessings, ect, hardly work for me.

I just want to let it all out through screaming, crying, punching, stomping, throwing and breaking things. It's so fast and I feel so great afterwards. But again, 2am, people are sleeping. And it's not very healthy in some cases.

I just don't get how people make the healthy releases work. If I'm not ugly crying, I'm not releasing any of my anxieties. And I just wish I could do some Yoga and get back to sleep!



Edit: I've also tried so many different substances, from chamomile tea, to valerian root, to many other things that are suppose to promote calmness, and sure they can help, but they never fix the anxiety to the point where I can go back to sleep.

title: Does anyone else act “crazy” during moments of high anxiety?
content: (22,F) Hello, currently in a state of heightened anxiety and have been for about 5ish hours. I’ve noticed sometimes when I’m having a lot of anxiety, especially over prolonged periods of time, sometimes I’ll act “crazy”. For example, humming/rocking, hitting myself on the chest, repetitive motions, moving in super slow motion, saying my thoughts out loud to myself/repeating them, widening my eyes, darting my eyes around the room, talking/texting in a weird grammatical patterns or with improper grammar, etc. I have the power to not do these things. For example if my boss were to show up on my doorstep and say we needed to have an urgent meeting immediately, I could pull myself together and act completely normal. But when I’m alone or with my partner I engage in these behaviors (in situations where I’m experiencing a lot of anxiety/before an anxiety attack or after). It sends me down a bit of a spiral, thinking I’m headed towards a nervous breakdown due to my anxiety, feeling weird about engaging in those behaviors even tho I could just stop, or worrying about myself and if I’m okay. But at the same time all of these behaviors are soothing, and help me to move through my anxiety and sometimes detach myself from the situation. Has anyone else experienced something similar? For the record I do understand a lot of these behaviors are stims or ways to self soothe. I do have ADHD, and I’d never find someone crazy for engaging in these behaviors to self soothe, or for other reasons. My thing is, when I do them, it feels like leaning into my anxiety. It doesn’t make me feel stable, or make me feel like I’m doing ok when I engage in these behaviors. Yet I continue to do them when I’m having a lot of anxiety, even tho it can cause me to spiral.  It’s a weird paradox, these behaviors soothe me while also causing me to spiral. It’s hard to explain so I hope I’m doing an alright job, any advice or suggestions or even just comments to say you relate would be appreciated.

title: i hate anxiety

title: My anxiety caused me to live on a beach for a year
content:
So, I just wanted to post this here because for years I’ve been battling severe anxiety. I was formally diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and I’ve been in psychotherapy for seven years. But yeah, I still deal with more anxiety than I want to. It’s been really tough. Sometimes it just feels like I’m alone in this, especially given how severe it’s been for me.

I’ll share a bit of my story. I basically went through extreme anxiety, got misdiagnosed, ended up living on a beach for a year because I thought that was gonna cure things - I thought going back to nature would heal me - threw away my entire life, then found a psychologist, and spent the last seven or eight years working to recover. But yeah, anxiety has really destabilized my life. Depersonalization has really destabilized my life. I’m just fighting to hold it together and not completely give up on my career path.

I’m a software engineer and have spent years building my career, but I’ve had a lot of challenges because of anxiety too. So yeah, I just wanted to share this. I’ve been scrolling through this community for years and finally built up the confidence to start putting myself out there.

title: Workplace anxiety tips
content:
Hello fellow redditors, 
I (19f) was recently successful in a job application at a small home wears store inside my local shopping centre. I have been successful with 6 job applications since I have turned 15, 3 of which I actually showed up to consistently due to debilitating anxiety/panic.

It’s really hard to me to explain my thoughts, feelings and symptoms to people or paint a picture of what I am experiencing. 
The best way I can describe it is increased heart rate, rapid mood changes, increased breathing, repeatedly going over thoughts, restlessness, headaches, light-headed, chills and a sense of fear. 
This usually happens prior to a shift more than during a shift. 

I try to remember that these feelings will pass and won’t last forever but they never do until I leave my shift or the job. I’ve struggled with a lot of insecurity and shame because of this because I feel like I should be doing a lot better at my age with work and money, but I know I’m not lazy because I love to learn and be busy. 

For background context, I have been officially diagnosed with bipolar 2, c-ptsd, adhd.
The jobs I have been successful with were a small grocery store, McDonald’s, a small pet grooming business, an automotive retail store, an optometrist and a large grocery store.

Any advice or suggestions on how to manage this and overcome this “fear” and anxiety, specifically mentally preparing before work and troubleshooting when an attack happens during a shift so that I can continue it, would be greatly appreciated. Thank you guys.

title: DAE have anxiety and also have a partner with anxiety?
content:

my question is how do you help your partner if you have different coping mechanisms? for example, when im anxious i need massive amounts of space and just need to get through it on my own.

however my boyfriend needs a lot of physical and emotional support. the problem im facing is that his anxiety is causing him to verbally lash out at me. he yells a lot and/or gets really irritated really easily. and he apologizes super quickly but then it takes me a while to move past him yelling at me.

title: Years of daily heart palpitations
content:
I have had generalized anxiety disorder for over ten years. I used to have panic attacks, but I don’t get them anymore. The anxiety quite manageable these past years, even though I experience it daily. However, I do have a lot of heart palpitations and it doesn’t seem to get any better. There isn’t a day where I don’t feel my heart trip/stumble or flutter like a butterfly. It can suddenly race, or pound, for no apparent reason. I feel it beat in my finger tips and I hear it in my ears. 


I’ve been to the doctor a few times in these past years, even once to the ER when my heart rate suddenly went to 180bpm for no reason. They didn’t find anything in all visits besides benign arrhythmias. I’ve done a few EKG’s, one echo, two bike stress tests, and twice a 24 hours heart monitor.


I’ve never met anyone that experiences anything even remotely similar. Most people tell me they’d be quite worried if they would have this. At the moment this is the only debilitating thing about my anxiety issues, because it does make me want to stay home often. 


I use meds for my anxiety, Wellbutrin. I don’t exercise, something I should do, and I struggle to manage to get a good night’s rest. But, I know a lot of people with similar or much worse habits (I worked in a techno club) that don’t experience any of these things physical symptoms. 


Is having these heart palpitations “normal” when you have an anxiety disorder?

title: Anyone else feel "diseased" when they wake up early in the morning?
content:
I've never been a morning person.  Ever since I turned 30, it's gotten worse.  I am now 41.   If I wake up before 8am, I feel like I have some undiagnosed disease.

I am slightly dizzy, usually have diarrhea, rapid heartbeat, fatigue, anxiety and nausea.  I've even thrown up a few times over the years from it.  If I get up before 8am, these symptoms usually stay with me for 6-8 hours and get better in the evening.

Luckily, I work for myself and get up usually at 8:30am or 9am without an alarm clock and almost all these symptoms are not an issue.  Usually just some fatigue.  After I shower, I feel great for the rest of day.

I'm "healthy" according to my primary doctor and cardiologist.  Blood work, PSA test, urinalysis and heart tests (ekg, echo and stress test) are normal.  Even was checked out by a neurologist and everything was fine.  My doctors say "you are young and healthy...go live your life."

I was diagnosed with anxiety about 10 years ago and started 75mg Effexor XR about five years ago.  It's really helped with my anxious way of thinking and I was hoping it would eleviate these early morning conditions but it has not.

I am at a healthy weight, walk my dogs 2-3 miles a day, eat 85% healthy and drink about 80oz of water a day.  I sleep 7-9 hours a night under a weight blanket and sleep like a baby.  

I always wanted a child but afraid I just will not be able to manage it with these uncomfortable, early morning symptoms.  I envy all my friends who get up at 5am and feel fantastic and ready to go.

Since all my physical tests come back normal, I have accepted my early morning symptoms as probably due to my anxiety disorder.  Even though I do not feel anxious anymore during the day.  Maybe I'll just have to live with these symptoms...

Any ideas on what to maybe try, please let me know 🙏
